My favorite part was that they bring the bill in a book. How original. This place is awesome. I still think about it, I wish we had something like it in Pittsburgh.
author: Amanda P.

description: Very classy, good selection of wine, dark, excellent music, good service, great decor.
author: Will D.

description:
The Hidden Vine is a great cozy place to enjoy a glass of wine or two.  I enjoyed a wine flight set of three and liked that they had a great selection of wines.  You can order by the glass, by three flights of wines, by comparison of two wines, or by the bottle.  

As far as food goes, they had various flatbreads, cheeses, pate, and more.  I had a mushroom flatbread with pesto that satisfied my savory craving that I was having.  

The service staff was friendly and attentive though sometimes it was hard to get service especially since the place was busy.
author: Caroline A.

description:
The Hidden Vine is indeed a 'hole in the wall' kind of place. I enjoyed the setting and seating area. It's quite cozy and appropriate for many different occasions. I enjoyed my glass of the Black Slate Garnacha (Cabernet Sauvignon). My friend tried the flights of Classic Cali; she was relatively pleased with the selection. We also ordered the Sottocenere cheese. I had never before had truffle cheese, so this was rather interesting. I really enjoyed the honeycomb and chutney on the plate too. My one complaint would be the scarcity of bread. 

Overall, I had a pleasant experience and would be back again.
author: C K.

description: I came here a little while ago on a work trip. I found the wine and have seen the lighted grapes. I like this place a lot. I and coworkers liked the atmosphere and the wine selections. But then I've never met a wine I didn't love lolz.
author: Funny R.

description: Love it!  Best wine bar I have been to...and shall I say one of the cleanest in the city??  The cost of glasses finally matches the atmostphere, an issue I run into a lot in SF.  The servers aren't always on par, but the wine and olives (only green, but damn they are good) cheese and snack offerings are great!  Great flight options!  Even have (2) three ounce pours rather than a full flight.  A bit expensive, but will definitely be back in the Financial District.  I love the cocktail tables and the communal for larger parties.
author: Candice H.

description: I love this place.  It is really small and cozy --- a great place for happy hour.  Really lively, but not too packed.  The wine menu is pretty extensive, but there's something for everyone.  I also highly recommend the trio of sliders -- delicious.  I think the beef/steak one was the best.  Will come back, for sure!
author: Mel G.

description:
This place has everything I look for in a wine bar - warm, inviting atmosphere that you can enjoy with a group or with one other friend; a good wine selection (obvs), but most importantly - a friendly, helpful bartender or waitress free of wine snobbery who help you select something you'd like (in this case, awesome, awesome friendly bartender); and yummy food to pair with the wine. I ordered a cheese plate, and the cheese portion was hefty and the honeycomb a super tasty addition. 

The icing on the cake with this place - they have a bocce ball court outside (LOVE LOVE) and you can host your birthday there. The helpful, informative bartender told me that music selections and outdoor heaters for the bocce ball court are coming soon!
author: Jeanna B.

description: This is a relatively small place tucked in an alley. I came in to meet with someone. they had a lot of available sofa's and seats, very cozy and comfortable place. They even had a little area for bocce ball. I was a little underwhelmed with the selection of wines. We ordered a charcuterie plate and based on the result, it must have been good. I only tried one of the pieces. I look forward to coming back and going a little deeper in.
author: Gabriel B.

description:
Went around town looking for another bocce ball place to play! Okay, we just searched yelp and found this great spot since the outside court at the park was reserved. 

Didn't sit in side at all or tried any wine, we went straight to the bocce out in their little courtyard and lucky us, no one was using it. Play a few games with a few beers, met some people, played with us, ended up being a great spot and a great night. Get hidden gem.
author: Annie D.

description:
I came here yesterday with a few gfs and found it to be VERY cozy and nicely decorated. Our waitress took a little time to take our orders but it was because quite a few ppl had showen up and she was the only one working. But when she took our order, she was very informed about what kind of wines they offer and suggested them accordingly. We ordered the italian white flights and a flight of reds. It comes with 3 samples and the waitress lined them up in the order that they should be tested. Our waitress..... i cannot emphasize... how ON POINT she was, i loved 2 out of the 3 italian whites that i had, only because the first inital one was kind of bland, but of course it wasn't anyon'es fault.

The atmosphere was very leisurely and kind of busy for a Tuesday night. For 2 flights (6 small samples) it came out to about $25 without tax. I would definitely tell ppl to check this place out
author: Elisa T.

description:
This is a jewel of a place that just opened a couple of months ago. We were staying in the financial district at La Meridian for a holiday event - wanted a light nosh before dressing for the party  - the concierge sent us to the Hidden Vine just around the corner!

They have an extensive wine collection, sparkling wines included.  But to my husbands delight they have a beer choice!  Liberty ale from Anchor Steam and a wheat beer called Speakeasy that was really great - light and refreshing.  

We ordered some olives - crisp and not too salty - and some almonds to much on - the almonds were blanched and devoid of skin - good but I prefer them raw and with skin.  There are more substantial things on the menu - which we will try next time!!

The bartender - wonderful, friendly, informed about the wines and beer, fabulous!  The wait staff equal to the bartender!  They tell me that it's crowded after work especially on Friday nights!  They open at 4PM - so if you want a seat, get there within 45 minutes of opening time.

They also have bocci ball!!  How fun is that!
author: Julie B.

description:
Wow, for the first time my fellow Yelpers let me down on this one. ;-)

After seeing over 300 reviews and a 4.5 star average I was excited to try this wine bar.  I have worked at a wine bar so I think I know a good one.

The +'s:
Worldly wine list in comparison to most wine bars - Austria, Lebanon, etc.
Quiet and comfortable seating
Service was ok once he got to us - took him 5 minutes to say hello

The -'s:
For such a wordly list, they had 3 reds from Unti winery in Sonoma.  Major flaw in my opinion as their wines are not that interesting and to have 3 is not a good way to compliment such a worldly list.  There are plenty of wines out there to choose from.
Pricing was just ok - I know what some of the wines cost so I was not overly impressed.

Overall, just ok for me...........

Gonz, over and out.
author: Chris G.

description:
Cute place, prices seemed reasonable, love how it's hidden away and that it's right next to a Czech bar actually owned by Czech people, so when you get drunk on wine and don't want to embarrass yourself, there's loud OomPah music (or top 40s) blaring and a party next door.

This is also the only Bocce court I've seen in SF and my friends love Bocce.

Friendly, unobtrusive staff makes this place great for a romantic evening.  Wouldn't bring a big group in here unannounced, but it seems they handle parties well.
author: Lauren J.

description: Well if you want to impress a woman  on a first / second date, here is where you should go. It's very classy with nice interior design. If you are a wine lover trying to have a real wine experience,  don't waste your time; there are better wine bars around.
author: Rozita N.

description:
Plenty of space on a Friday night to grab a glass of wine in a flight. It has the oversized, luxurious ambiance of a Napa living room, a great surprised tucked into a quiet, random alley!

Mid-week (Wednesday or Thursday) it gets much busier, so go early or expect to get clever with seating.

They do have small bites to munch on alongside the wine, which I'd love to go back and try.

The downside about this place, which you'll need to prepare for, is the brusque to borderline hostile service. It's happened at least twice for me, and threatens the ambiance. If you don't mind, you'll love it here. If you do, you may still find the Hidden Vine an appealing last resort.
author: Megan G.

description: Amazing happy hour deals but suffers a little from the location (Embarcadero 2).  I do love this place and it's steps from my office but hopefully more people catch on to the fact that there is a solid wine bar steps from your desk. (or maybe people just prefer to do their 'wining' within stumbling distance from their beds?)
author: Mike V.

description:
I went here about 3-4 times.  Initially, I thought it was a great locals place (when I lived there), even though the cheese plates and the like were disappointing.  The service was good the first few visits and the ambience very enjoyable.
  
But the last time I went it was a little busier, and they did not seem to be able to handle a "crowd."  I was in a small group of 4-5 people and we tried to sit in an empty area together and moved two of the seats closer.  The server came over quickly, and without saying anything started to move the chair with one of the ladies sitting in it!  He rudely said that the chair couldn't be there because he had to walk through that area to get wine.  Completely understandable, but he could have just asked nicely.  That wasn't it though, he continued to be rude and was obviously flustered and seemed overwhelmed by the rest of the people in there.
That was the last time I was there.  Found a nice wine bar on the west side instead.  A little further from where I was, but worth it.
author: Oceanus P.

description:
I wasn't sure if I wanted to give it 1 or 2 stars, so I went higher to be nicer. Here's why:

1) They do NOT offer a comp cheese plate on Thursday per their website: http://www.thehiddenvine.com/events.shtml "Ongoing Events
Join us for our weekly complimentary cheese board, Thursdays from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m.". Server informed us they haven't done that at least since he started in January

2) They do NOT have the following on the menu to order: Miller Farms Olive Oil & Garlic Roasted Walnuts or Five Star Chocolate Truffles
http://www.thehiddenvine.com/menu.shtml. This menu is online & posted at bar entrance. Again, server said they haven't had those since he started there. 

3) They do NOT offer "Flights of the Month" per their website: http://www.thehiddenvine.com/events.shtml. 

4) The cheese plate was so-so. 2 choices for $12 with ~10 tiny bread slices & a small souffle cup of chutney. The cuts of cheese probably range between 1.5-2 oz each so ok for 2 people to split but you're still hungry after. 

5) And since we were still hungry, we got the Wild Boar salami which also came w/ some sliced bread (which is what we were after). The salami had a good flavor & good marbling but it was severly cold and hard. It was more like eating jerky than salami which threw off the texture. 

Both did comparisons.
1st: Sav Blanc comparison for both of us. They were OK, nothing spectacular & I'd never buy a full bottle of either. 
2nd: I did Zin comparison & my friend did Pinot comparisons. Again, only OK wines. 
Server seemed to be knowledgeable about the wines but we didn't ask too many questions. He did acknowledge that it was embarrassing the website & outdoor menu were so blatantly off & not at all updated.

The interior is eclectic/funky & music plays in the background. Very dark so when you come in from the outside, your eyes have to adjust to the lighting & it's a flight of stairs down so hold on to the handrail! At least our couches were comfy to sit on!

I'll check out other wine bars before I go back here. Glad we had a Groupon for this.
author: Marissa H.

description:
There's a reason why I went to the Hidden Vine twice in two nights:  It's GOOD.

In fact, this has been the third time in three months I've been to this venue.  The first time I went on a date (early last month).  The second time this past Thursday with a friend.  The third time this past Friday with a friend where we had good wine, cheese and some bread with honey.  Man, the snacks were awesome.

Why is it I like this place a lot?  Well, it's a very chill atmosphere inside and the service, wine and food seem to go with it.  Just think of yourself relaxing at a nice hotel in Carmel, California where everything is tranquilized and drama is down.  That's what the Hidden Vine is like.  The ambiance was good as well.  Hell, it's a perfect place for working professionals to mingle, dating and meeting new people in general.  There's a nice outdoor area to get some air.  Pretty unique venue considering it's sandwiched in the alley of Merchant right next to Battery.

To someone who had pointed out that the hostess was rude at Hidden Vine, nope, not in my experience.  The offerings not cheap?  This is San Francisco folks.  GET USED TO IT.  We aren't a third world country.  There are a lot worse venues than the Hidden Vine so if you go ahead and criticize it, you might as well criticize the city of Carmel.

And yes, if someone at Hidden Vine tells you you should make reservations next time, it's because they are trying to be fair to other customers.  You don't like it, go someplace else.  I chose to continue going to the Hidden Vine and I'll refer all my friends and colleagues to go there.  I'm even working on organizing a networking event myself there as a matter of fact and managed to get the contact information of the events coordinator at the Hidden Vine, as well as additional information regarding event organization, pricing, head count, etc.  All this was because I guess I'm smooth but some reviewers here need to learn some people communication skills.

Anyway, have fun with the Hidden Vine.  It's good.
author: M B.

description: Amazing staff and a great selection of diverse wines from around the world. Oh, and an outdoor bocce court.
author: Liz W.

description:
This place is just another wine bar in the financial district, except for one distinct difference. Bocce Ball. I mean come on wine and bocce ball? Super fun, anyways i had a blast coming here the other day, which was a bit of a slow night, and had several games of bocce ball while hanging out with friends. Although i did not drink that night, their selection of wines, was large and was in the most part decent from speaking with friends. 

I will be back to try again in the future.
author: Benjamin L.

description: Wonderful hidden gem. My boyfriend and I went here the other night to end date night with some glasses of wine. LOVED the cozy atmosphere! Great flight selections and cheese/meat selections. A must try are their lobster rolls!!
author: Shanna M.

description:
I like this place because it is hidden. It is small and cozy. 

I went there with my friends on a Friday and it got really crowded as we were leaving. We got there early and so we had a table but I cant imagine being able to get a table if you get there after 7 on weekends. 

Service was okey. The wine list is decent and the cheese plates are not horrible, theyr ok. 

All in all its a wine bar that id go back to.
author: Kajal P.

description: Very nice and cozy location. Good place to have a conversation (low noise level) and relax from all your worries :)
author: Alex C.

description:
Great little spot right in the Fi-Di.  The inside has a nice bar up front and a bunch of tables and booths throughout.  It has that kind of warm, den ambiance, except with music, talking, and wine!  
There's an outdoor area with a Bocce court.  I didn't try it because it was raining, but it looked like people were having fun there.  We sat at the bar, had a couple wine flights and glasses, and a cheese plate.  The wines were great, and the cheese plate had some great honey and quince with it.  The bartenders and staff there were great, we were chatting with them throughout the evening.
No happy hour prices, and the lowest price glass was probably $9, so it's probably not an every day place, but definitely a good spot to check out.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
My friend was in town and we were looking for a solid wine bar to hit up after work on a Friday. We popped in and it was packed, a good sign that we had found a good spot. 

We had the Say What?! and Portuguese white flights, as well as the olives, marcona almonds, and the mushroom flatbread (flatbread? Let's be honest--if there's a crispy crust, cheese, and toppings, I think we can all agree it's pizza). The waitress was attentive but not pushy, and the leather couch we sat in for two and a half hours was a great end to a Friday.

Would definitely go back. The 50% off a glass of wine with a Yelp check-in didn't hurt either.

The good: tasty food and reasonable flights. 
The bad: crowded and takes a while to find an open table. B-e aggressive.
author: Amanda B.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday and we got to drink wine and play bocce ball!  What more could you ask for?  We had the whole place to ourselves which was pretty awesome.  The interior of The Hidden Vine looks like someone's living room.
author: Carli F.

description: Such an great little wine bar.  I am a certified sommelier and I was very impressed when I looked at their wine list.  They have unique wines that many people have probably never even heard of. And their prices are great.  The staff is also awesome.  You can tell they love their job, which makes customers love being in the presence.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Yes, I was the guy who ordered a beer here at a wine bar so take this review with a grain of salt I guess.  

The ambiance and decor were absolutely perfect for this venue.  We had just flown all the way from DC and taken BART up from SFO.  Just a couple block walk away was the Hidden Vine where we were meeting up with family before heading over to Le Colonial across the street for dinner.  

We just stopped for quick drinks here but from our short visit I was very impressed with both the decor and the selection.  Our server was actually very good as well, very knowledgable, and quick with our order.  

We didn;t spend too much time here but the short time we did spend was absolutely perfect.  The place has an amazing little boutique charm, and our quiet corner was just the perfect oasis to start our visit after a long day of flying and the train in from the airport.
author: Christopher T.

description: Super Nice atmosphere. A good place for a date or drinks with your besties after work. Friendly waiters too. We had the Cabernet Sauvignon for $44, flatbread for $12 (looked like a frozen pizza), burrata and salat. Quite expensive ($100) but the location pays off.
author: Chris S.

description:
Enjoyed this place very much. Thanks to Yelp we stumbled upon this on a recent vacation to SF. 

Service was great, helpful, knowledgable servers. We where able to try some great, new wines we would have never found by ourselves.

I also tried 2 of the 3 beers they offer, both full of flavor and went great with our cheese.  Try the home made spicy apple chutney.

Loved the cozy, "living room" style atmosphere. Music was also great on our 2nd visit, the Modest Mouse Pandora station was playing.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Love the Bocce court here... except there is only 1 court so reservations are needed and hard to get. 

Wine menu is great but pricey. Food menu- not a fan. Wish it  has more good after work snacks instead of really expensive appetizer options. 

All in all a good spot and I really enjoy the bocce court! Great for a small group outing!
author: Kimberly M.

description: Love this place for the bocce ball and quiet atmosphere.  The wines can be hit or miss, but the upside is that the servers are very helpful and accommodating. The food was disappointing and I won't be returning hungry.
author: Lindsay B.

description: One of the greatest finds in San Francisco off of the beaten track in a bit of an alley-like block. Wonderful ambience - especially if you land in the seats in front of the fireplace. There's a private area to host private parties and an outdoor area for a round of bocce ball. They have a vast selection of wines and finger foods. It tends to get crowded though so come a bit early for happy hour or during a weekday for some R&R!
author: Trang H.

description:
All I wanted was something loungy and low-key for my birthday, and The Hidden Vine delivered on both accounts.  Fabulous wine, cheese plate, and XOX truffles were just an incredible bonus.

I'm pretty clueless when it comes to wine and our waiter was awesomely helpful in this regard.  He explained a ton, gave us recs for his favorites, and his enthusiasm for wine (and cheese!) clearly showed.  

They have the menu set up so you can order a variety of flights depending on featured region, comparisons of reds or whites, and even dessert wines where you can choose three you like.  Portions are generous and reasonably priced and I loved that each glass of wine comes with a label so that you can 1) remember what the heck your drinking, and 2) if you like it, you can remove the label and haul ass to the nearest BevMo for more.

My friends did a variety of dessert wines, while I choose a flight of reds from the featured region of the month: Israel and Lebanon.  Two of the wines were from Yarden, a winery that I just happened to visit while in the far north of Israel a couple years ago.  Ah, memories.  Couldn't have been a better birthday treat.

The food options are somewhat simple since they really focus on the wines here.  Still, I loved the cheese plate with the amazing Humboldt Fog goat cheese, bread, tomato tapenade, and bits of fruit. 

Choices for restaurants and bars are always limited near Union Square, and The Hidden Vine is a great find for the neighborhood.  I most definitely will be back!
author: Joanne G.

description:
I have nothing but good things to say about Hidden Vine. 

I hosted my companies anniversary party at Hidden Vine, the staff met all my expectations and helped to make the evening really special. 
I had help every step of the way in the planning process and night of everything went off without a hitch. 

Thank you Hidden Vine staff for helping to make a wonderful event for my company.
author: Rose M.

description:
AMAZING place!! It's actually hidden in the financial district on a side street. I found this place by mistake last weekend and it ended up being the best mistake ever!

I had a couple three glasses of the zin they have on the menu which was amazing, and my boyfriend had some delicious beers they have on tap that he'd never hears off. 

The best part was the bocce ball! They have a super cute full size bocce court outside. Usually its reserved and you have to by worth $100 worth in order to match with your reservation. There were no reservations on the Saturday night we went though so we didn't have a drink minimum and we were able to challenge some different couples to bocce. It was really!

Everyone who works there is unbelievably nice and helpful. The manager even wrote me a lost of restaurants to try in my area because I just moved to sf a couple of weeks ago. 

Great experience at the Hidden Vine! I can't wait to take all of my coworkers and friends to this place!
author: Juliet S.

description:
I went here with a friend of mine the other night for the first time, spent way too much money, drank way too much wine, and generally just had a great time. We had a few bottles of this ridiculously good rose' (of course I can't remember the name), and after the waiter dropped a knife on my knee (no harm done) he gave us both glasses of a sparkling rose' - on the house. 

The food menu is limited, but the sliders are good- really really good. 

Very cute little place. Did I mention they have an indoor bocce court?!? Definitely going to need to get in on that next time.
author: Mel P.

description: Was thrilled to find a bocce court in the middle of the city! After a phenomenal birthday dinner at Kokkari on a Friday evening not too long ago, my friends (about 12 of us) moseyed on over the Hidden Vine for some bocce and wine. It reminds me of a cozy library or study, except there is wine instead of books! I was super impressed with how communicative and friendly Danielle was when I had to update the reservation size a couple of times. Also, the guy serving us was absolutely on point. We were scattered all throughout the bar. Some were even outside playing bocce (1 hour reservations for $100 minimum worth of wine - easy to get to with a party of 12). He'd come over and take our order and even if we moved, he'd find and bring each of us our wine. Will defo be back!
author: Mindy J.

description:
Loved this place. I visited late on Thursday and it was easy to get a comfy/romantic spot. We had a cheese plate that was great, I highly recommend the goat but the sheep was great too! 

The pours are generous and the staff are really helpful in making suggestions or providing samples. 

I will be going back for sure! See you soon Hidden Vine with your delicious wine and cheese.
author: Brandi b.

description: What a hidden gem. The service was tremendous, great selection of wines and the flights were perfect. Only thing that was odd is that I almost turned around and left because the place looked closed literally until I opened the door. Light was off on sign.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Great wine! Great vibe! It's like a really big living room with lots and lots of wine.
author: Three D.

description: WOWSA! You need a cold shower after visiting, 'cause it's just romantic and sexy and all that. Great wine, great food and the atmosphere! Love the decor and feel of the place. Yet another San Fran gem.
author: Jesus R.

description:
2.5?

I don't know much about wine, I'll be honest.  I had two guests from France stay with me and they wanted to try California wine so I yelped 'wine bars' and decided to try Hidden Vine.

We got there around 10:20pm and the woman at the bar apologised but said that she would have to close early because the closer didn't come and she needed to catch the Bart.  So that left us with 30 minutes to chug down $10 - $14 glasses of wine.  We could have easily gone elsewhere but we had walked a good amount of blocks to get there so that was a bit of a bummer.

I had a sparkling rose wine for $7.  I picked the cheapest glass of the menu because i know the Frenchies were going to pay.  They both ordered two glasses of California wine and weren't impressed.  They used words like 'strong' to describe them.  They could have just been picky also, but for $37 it wasn't worth it.  

Also my fourth friend ordered water and it never came.  The server seemed a little put out that he ordered water and not wine.
author: Walerz B.

description: This place is awesome and I can't wait to get back for my next trip to SF in August. The staff is so knowledgable and nice and the wine was amazing. Bocci ball on the patio with great music is the way to spend a lazy Sunday or Monday afternoon.
author: Andrea A.

description:
Went for a friend's interesting exploration of the up and coming fair trade wine industry.  Think "organic wines" of 10 years ago, prior to biodynamic.  They were interesting... 

2007 Fairhills Malbec from South Africa (round and fruity front with earthy dirt lingering)
2008 Fairhills Merlot from Argentina (sweet and playfully fruity)
2008 Fairhills Cabernet from South Africa (big... tannins were light even though it tasted like a shale cliff from the desert.  I really liked it but "earth" is the word in every sense.

That tasting was $8. That's insane.  They were not special wines, nor were they something I would have ever a) bought or b) tasted...... but they were certainly worthy of a tasting, and at $8 that is ASTONISHING.

Then I graduated myself (complete applause) to a bubbly "VS" from the menu that is pretty smart.  It's a smaller tasting in general for the client - but it's also less stock, less labor, and easier to mark up.  The price was a completely fair - I think it was $16, but it could have been cheaper.  The VS is a fun idea.... Two instead of three.... a head to head experience.

NV Tenuta di Collalbrigo Prosecco Rosé Veneto, Italy 
vs.
MV Bailly-Lapierre Brut, 'Exception' Cremant de Bourgogne Burgundy (is that right?)

I like bubbly. I quite enjoyed both, but I don't think the Prosecco was a fresh bottle.  I guess it's always okay to ask?  I don't know... now I am rambling. Isn't that quaint.

In the end, for a well situated amble towards dinner, we were rosy and pleasured at no more than $29 total before tip.  That's fairly cool for a wine bar.

Quite enjoyed.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Grabbed a quick celebratory glass of wine here last Friday. Warm, inviting and friendly. The charcuterie plate was the perfect snack while we enjoyed a couple of glasses of wine. Great spot.
author: Joe O.

description:
This place has a very unique mood that makes it perfect for the kind of night out that feels like a night in. Unlike some other wine bars, you can hear your companion without asking them to scream into your ear, so I choose to go here when talking is the main objective of my night out. Basically, you can't come here expecting to be entertained-- like others have written, this place looks like a living room. No frills, really, so bring  your own fun. 

They have a pretty good variety of wines, but it gets pretty expensive (not to mention intoxicating) trying glass after glass of wine, so I recommend getting the flights (starting ~$13) and some olives/nuts to pace yourself.
author: Saori E.

description:
I really enjoyed Hidden Vine.  I thought the place was quite interesting and had comfortable seating.  The staff was really friendly and helpful when needed, meaning they didn't bug you too much.

Very long wine list, but at least they break it up into different sections (i.e. earthy, full-bodied and so on).   Also, I thought the music choice of Arcade Fire, etc. was quite interesting but added to the experience.
author: J. S.

description:
I am actually a little tempted to not review this location in order to keep it as a cozy, obscure, hole in the wall that it is today. This place is very quiet, there is always seating available, and they are very generous with their tastings and they definitely take their wine seriously. The selection is vast for reds, though I have stopped by on evenings when they ran out of any labels of sauvignon blanc. They also have many snacks to pair with your wine, such as baguette with pate or a cheese plate. 

If you are looking for a quiet wine bar and you happen to be in the neighborhood, I can't imagine a better place to go.
author: Tian X.

description: Great ambiance, great wine, great cheese, best chutney I have ever had in my life (on the cheese plate). I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a nice glass of wine and cheese board.
author: Jay W.

description: 5 stars for the ambience and relative secrecy. The vibe is sexy, sophisticated, mysterious. Great wine selection too, though I tend to only order sweet and white wines. The Hidden Vine is everything I want in a wine bar.
author: Jenny T.

description: I had REALLLLLY high hopes for this place. Wine - just ok, I had the Pinot flight, and honestly have had much much better Pinot, we are in CA here people. Service was spotty, the waitress came back a lot but took awhile to get us menus. They ran out of bread (HOW DOES A WINE BAR RUN OUT OF BREAD?!?). They also were out of the best cheese offered with the cheese plate, and offered to swap out for our favorite of the ones we had. We choose to get a second helping of the Gouda, but instead of two pieces (like all the other cheese varietals on the plate) we just got one, seriously? We had a Syrah to finish off the night that was just ok as well. All in all, expected MUCH more for $120, with 4 glasses of wine, a cheese plate and 2 apps. Probably wouldn't recommend unless you are drinking beer and playing the bocce court outside (was packed the entire time we were there on a Wed night).
author: Jared G.

description:
Definitely would never go back or recommend it to a friend.  Highly overpriced, especially the food, say $250 for a measly portion of sliced meat and cheese and a 21% gratuity on top of that. Yes, a $52 tip for carrying out a platter and setting it down!  Somehow this should be illegal.  As if that isn't enough, we bought wine by the bottle and took it with us unopened and were charged 21% gratuity on THAT wine.  Now I know that must be illegal, but if not certainly poor management.  When asked if we could adjust the service charge down, we were told by Danielle, the manager that we had to pay the gratuity which was ended up being over $150 for zero service.  
Go play Bocce somewhere else and let this place wither on the vine.  It isnt nearly as good as it thinks it is!
author: Sandy D.

description: Cozy, intimate, casual, European feel in a wide open California city. Lovely wine and food menu for anyone's appeal.
author: Beth N.

description: Quite a nice little spot for a glass of wine in the financial district.  Not oversubscribed and a nice selection of glasses and flights.
author: Eric W.

description: Awesome place for a beverage. My wife and I went after work for some wine and flatbread. The atmosphere was very laid back and welcoming. Wish we were outside playing on the bocce ball court but there were a ton of folks out there.
author: Sean S.

description:
After giving it a couple more chances in the wake of the original owners' departure, I am incredibly sad to report the magic is gone at The Hidden Vine.  The buyers kept the comfy chairs, the rotating monthly tasting flight menu and the low lighting, but they cannot recreate the alchemy.  And what makes me sad is they don't even seem to try.  

Wine bars are practically cropping up on every corner in this city - but simply having a wine list will not make you a great place.  That takes time, care and an enjoyment of the clientele and product that I have not seen in the latest incarnation of the Hidden Vine.   The list might bring me back, but more likely I will be on the hunt elsewhere, looking for that magic.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
The Hidden Vine is the perfect place to enjoy a glass or bottle of wine with friends or that special someone in your life. 

We chose to enter through the hotel lobby which was quite unique. The lobby is old and you'll wonder, is this really as good as everyone says it is. Please keep going because it's better than everyone says it is! 

Our group didn't have anything to eat since we had dinner reservations later, but the wine was fantastic and reasonably priced. There was even a wine conisseur amongst us who was pleased. 

The staff is extremely knowledgeable and the service was perfect.
author: Roland W.

description:
I've only been here once but I'm already hooked.

I walked in and the place smelled like wine in a way I'd expect an oak tree to smell like oak. It is a very small room with a small bar that somehow manages to fit several tables together in a very spacious arrangement.

Their wine list is wonderful and full of gems.  I am a Riesling lady and enjoyed many a glass of the 2007 Jana 'Old Vine' Riesling, Napa Valley.  I once strayed during the evening from my dearest Riesling and tried the Naumann Vineyards Chardonnay.  Can you say, heavenly?

The service and knowledge of their staff was superb. They picked both of my wine choices. I highly enjoyed myself. Thumbs up to The Hidden Vine for making my night wonderful.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I've definitely found my new favorite wine bar! The Hidden Vine reminds me of what I can only imagine every grandma's living room looking like. It's warm, cozy, quiet and has a friendly-neighborhood vibe. 

They have an extensive wine list as well as some cheese platters (which I didn't sample). They aren't kidding with the "Hidden," though because if you're not really paying attention you'll pass right by the tiny plaque that indicates it's inside the Fitzgerald Hotel. 

This is a great spot for a mellow evening out with friends, a date, or even just on a cold winter eve when you want to get out of your apartment. Enjoy!
author: Julia N.

description:
TK and I headed to The Hidden Vine a few weekends ago and am looking forward to going back again soon. We stopped in before dinner for drinks (we ordered an Italian red wine flight and a Green Flash Trippel) and snacked on Iberico and Humboldt Fog cheeses along with some salumi. We were tucked away in a corner and enjoyed the quiet, relaxing ambience along with great service. 

At dinner we met an awesome couple celebrating their one year anniversary (congrats Steve and Jared!) and after pounding sake for the past few hours at dinner we drunkenly decided going back to The Hidden Vine for more drinks was a smart idea. More wines, more beers, and a tasty flight of dessert wines later we were by far the loud, obnoxious, very drunk table. And the staff was still very nice to us although the other patrons may not have been as amused. 

Thanks for putting up with us Hidden Vine, I'll be back - and I promise everyone will keep their clothes on next time. Maybe. 

peace, love, and good booze ~ chase
author: Chase S.

description: Can't review the wine yet, but popped in for a few minutes and love the chill vibe and comfortable seating.  So calm and warm.  Fireplace is a nice touch.  Cool location hidden in a little alley next to Cafe Prague.
author: April M.

description:
Talk about hidden! It took quite a few rounds of circling the neighborhood only to find it secretly resting in an alleyway. This self-seated lounge is small and homey, intimate and quiet. Perfect spot to bring a date. Staffs are friendly, attentive and very helpful when it comes to recommendation. They offer a great selection of wine and salumi cured meats, olives, cheese, fruits and nuts to pair with.

Wine lovers will not be complaining.
author: Jenny K.

description: Great service! The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. I recommend taking advantage of their "flights," "comparisons," and "slider trio" if you're in an indecisive mood. Thank you!!
author: Robert W.

description:
This is a great spot to show your girl you've got some class, have a nice chill conversation, and a little privacy.  Went on a weeknight and it had the perfect number of customers to make a little background noise but not ruin the vibe.

Great place for a date, not super cheap, but hey, you're drinking good wine and eating classy cheese, not getting all-you-can-eat breadsticks at The Olive Garden, mmm, breadsticks.  

Not the best of places to flex your wine acumen, as the staff are really knowledgeable, have great suggestions and comparisons to try.  As is true in many other parts of life, it is better to ask questions than strut your stuff here.  You may learn something, and you will definitely  please your palette.

PS-it's inside the Fitzgerald Hotel, so don't miss it!
author: Justin B.

description:
Really, who wouldn't love a cozy wine bar with romantic mood lighting and velvet chairs tucked away in a tiny hotel near Union Square? 

I went with a couple of friends and we decided to start with the flights (two of us had the rose/white flight and the third had the sparkling).  I liked that they put little labels around the stems of the glasses with the names and years of the wines so we could remember what we were drinking.  We ended up ordering a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc from their extensive wine list and enjoyed it with some cheese and crackers (two cheeses and baguette $9) and a persimmon spread on the side.  Delish!

This is the perfect place to visit if you're in the Union Square area and want to have a quiet drink before or after dinner or a show.  I would never have known about this place if I hadn't seen it on Yelp because it's tucked away inside a tiny hotel, but I'm glad I did and plan on going back again soon.  I can't wait to bring my wine-loving friends here!
author: Kimberly B.

description: Really a hidden gem of the city, great for just chillin or reading a book and some wine. The hostesses are very knowledgeable and will give you a good selection.
author: Alvin L.

description: Came here last night for New Years Eve for the hours before the SF fireworks display. Loved it. Intimate and cozy. Good wine. Friendly, good natured atmosphere. The staff was awesome; friendly, attentive and worked as a team. One thing that stood out for me additionally was that one of the local crazies did come in, but wasn't causing any problems, just was friendly to the patrons. The staff handled him with dignity and were low key about the whole thing. I really like this place and will definitely be back in future trips to the city.
author: Dana P.

description:
We were early for our reservation at Fino and decided to stop in here for a drink to kill some time.  This little place is was the perfect place to get away from the rain and unwind from the hectic drive over the bridge before enjoying our dinner.  It's super secluded, and has a great homey feel like you're relaxing in a friend's living room not expected to swirl and sip like a pro in some stuffy wine bar. 

I love that their selections are broken up by characteristic, not necessarily by region or grape variety.  They also have some well priced tasting flights, and though we just stuck to our single glasses, I plan to come back for a more well-rounded experience very soon.

The staff was small, only one woman working there, but she was friendly and very helpful without being overly attentive.  

Bottom line: A great place to escape, I'll definitely be back.  I'd tell you to go here, but I want to keep it all to myself!
author: Kellie T.

description: It truly is hidden. Amazing ambiance, decent music (though a little too mellow). They have an awesome selection of wine and a couple of beers on tap. The service is awesome. Great for a romantic evening/afternoon.
author: Rohit M.

description: cute little place for wine and bocci. although someone else was occupying the court for a few hours, I would come back.  I wish they could limit the time spent on the court.  I like this cute secluded bar.
author: Ting B.

description:
Cozy hole In the wall are you nuts!!
This place needs CPR! I was looking for a cool place to hang out have a glass of wine and listen to some music. 
I would have fallen asleep within 10 minutes if I stayed, dull dull dull
author: Mike B.

description: Short of Napa Valley vineyards, this place is hands down THE BEST wine bar I've been to in the entire country. We paid like $15.00 for an 8 glass flight. It was glorious. The wine was delicious. The waiter was so cute. Everyone was so nice. The cheese place was delicious. Highly recommended. Very romantic. Very awesome.
author: Johnny B.

description: This place was really classy and a good place to hang out. We just went for drinks before going to the theater about a block away. Wine was good, atmosphere was nice. They were having a birthday party or something in the entry room but it wasn't loud or distracting. Didn't try the food but prob is expensive ;)
author: Katrina F.

description: Really cool wine bar off the beaten path in the Financial District with it's own bocce ball court (lane?). There are a ton of big comfy chairs in the bar, definitely a good place to grab a glass of wine and relax with friends after work. Went on a Thursday and it was a pretty good scene (although flow of the bar doesn't really encourage mingling). Would definitely go back, especially to play bocce!
author: Gina C.

description: Sweet hidden bocce court and wine. Sometimes I wonder how dangerous of a combination that actually is.
author: Dora C.

description:
Definitely "hidden" - as it is inside the Hotel Fitzgerald. 

Cozy inside but with GREAT staff and lots of wines to choose from. The wait staff are knowledgeable and I highly recommend ordering one of their well poured flights so you can try a variety of wines. 

They have a small amount of small plates (olives, cheeses, etc - if you need a snack!). 
This is a great alternative if the Redwood Room is packed and cheesy that night!
author: Jessica L.

description: This place is a great little hidden gem! Although it's a bit dark, the wine and cheese selection more than make up for it! Been here a few times and just loved it!
author: Kelly B.

description:
For a date, this place is great. It's a very intimate, cozy wine bar with plush seats, mostly small circular tables, quick service and a fine menu. 

For large groups, however, this place is difficult. After my singles' group tried to make a reservation for sixteen and was told that they did not make reservations for such a large number of people, we arrived and began to take the available tables for four, but a waitress informed us that we could only take three such tables - not four - because they did not want us "overrunning the place." What??? They'd rather have a fourth table remain empty, with some of our party members just waiting outside or going next door? They did allow us to reserve the cute bocce ball court  but told us that a.) we'd need a $100 tab to keep it reserved (a little exigent on their part, but no problem for us) and b.) that we could only have twelve people on the court - no rotating in - or they'd charge us $20 for each additional person who played bocce. No one else even signed up to use bocce that evening.   

Some of my other friends are going to the Hidden Vine again this week; I hope to be able to give a better report from them.
author: El G.

description:
We returned here after the showing at Curran and we were surprised that there were seats available.  We clinched the seat by the alley window (so not much view) - but it was so well done, they had cushions by the window, two more chairs and a small round table, surrounded by frisky, avant-garde parisian fabric art pieces.

The wine menu here is definitely off the beaten path but very easy to navigate through - they break out wines by fruity/jammy, earthy,or  bold, for the reds, crispy, silky, or fruity for the whintes.  they also have a limited menu of charcuteries and cheesses - so don't go here hungry.

Definitely a hidden gem in the nob hill/tenderloin area.
author: Mike P.

description:
For the life of me I can't figure out why people liked this place. It's very "mom and pop" shop-like. They really do try to spruce the place up with the decor but it still feels cheap. Wine only here - no liquer or beer. I half expected my glass of wine to be served in a paper cup...

Also hidden vine is incredibly small. If you're alone or with a group of four or under then you're probably alright. Keep in mind this place is located inside the lobby of a cheap hotel.   

The do have a good selection of local and foreign wines.
author: John Z.

description: A hidden gem for sure. Incredible decor (dark woods, brick, leather chairs/sofas), great service, good selection of wine. We tried the flat bread and a cheese selection - amazing, get it. Id recommend it as a good spot for drinks with good friends, or a place to impress someone special.
author: craig s.

description:
I have come to the possible conclusion that since I have been working at the library for close to a decade that when I go out to dine or drink, I prefer a quiet and intimate location. But the main reason I really enjoy this type of location is because I believe in the illusion that I have found a hidden gem.

Entering through the back entrance of The Hidden Vine and walking down to a cozy basement type lounge area, I felt like I was invited into a small little get together with good friends. I had chance to enjoy some nice wine and cheeses while taking in the ambience and conversation. It helps to be with good company too!
author: Sam T.

description:
I really enjoyed my evening at the Hidden Vine.  As the name implies it's a bit of a hidden gem, tucked away on Merchant street off of Battery.  I enjoyed the space inside ... the whole place felt cozy but not stuffy, and at the same time the high ceilings and lighting gave an open, refreshing vibe.  :P Well, that's what I felt anyway.  It had a chill atmosphere, no pretentiousness.  Just folks out for a nice glass of wine and good conversation.  The bartender, Cassidy, gave awesome recommendations on wine.  As for the food the pear dessert was so-so but the trio of sliders and flat bread were pretty good.  

I highly recommend  :)
author: H K.

description:
Well, when in Rome...

Anyone who may know me, might also know that I arrive to almost every party late.  I don't mean literally (I'm quite punctual, thank you) but rather figuratively. 

I'm a late bloomer across many if not all aspects of my life, first time eating a tomato - age 12, first kiss - age 18, first time eating an egg - age 26....the list of late arrival is lengthy (as well as embarrassing). So it's no surprise that I am pretty green on topic of wine. Up until I recently it was seen as just yucky grape juice.

Pallet, undertones, finish, tannins...all terms belonging to other areas of study. But at the Hidden Vine, with coaxing and tutelage from some knowledgeable acquaintances, last night I received a crash course.

We were served our flights, each presented with little cards showing the region, type and year displayed for personal edification. The server was extremely well mannered and friendly, with a propensity toward offering piquant little tastes of fun wines.

The location was much like a darkened little den tucked away inside an equally little hotel, with soft furniture, dim lights and relaxed atmosphere I was totally at home (love tiny spaces). It was pretty much where I expected wine snobbery to take place, and it did, and it was great.

Drinks with friends, learning about wine (yay multi-tasking) it was a great finish to the day.
Alright! I now have wine under my belt, up next...canned tuna fish.
author: Sarah M.

description: Cute place, nice wine selection. Little hard to chat if you are seated at the bar if there's more than 2 of you. They take reservations for 6+ people which is nice, but they do require you to be pretty on time and all people in attendance (which can be kinda hard to manage with some people)...Good food, good wine, relaxing place...what's not to like! Will be back again!
author: Denise V.

description: Cool spot on a FiDi alley.  They did a decent job on the interior.  Location is a bit off though.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I've been here a bunch but we had a work event there yesterday and it was PERFECT. The people that work there are friendly, knowledgeable and make for an awesome experience. The place itself is really neat with the brick walls, fireplace and BOCCE BALL court.
I'd suggest this place to anyone whether it's a drink after work, a night out on the weekend or for a work event.
Oh yeah, and the food was delicious
author: C E.

description:
I've never been to a place where the experience was so utterly ruined by bad service.  The waiter did anything but  - he would literally dart away every time I tried to ask a question.  The place was only half full, yet he was charging around like a McDonald's employee during lunch hour with a cattle prod up his bum.  He wasn't the only one there either, but I guess his time was short what with trying to engage the blonde girl at the bar in conversation.

Others have complained rightly about the lack of interest by the current management in their craft.  Their wine flights are hit and miss.  It's hard to screw up reds, but the whites, Rieslings and the sparkling wines were very inconsistent.  It'd have been useful to know that two of the three Rieslings were so sweet that a reviewer would have mentioned notes of Gatorade.  They also offer a cheese plate, and for $12 you get 4 tiny slivers of cheese, adding further insult.

It is a really nice place inside, the atmosphere and decor are fantastic - but as others have mentioned, this is the work of the original owners who loved their wines and established the business.  All that remains are nice couches, and if you don't really care what your booze tastes like, I suppose this is the place for you.
author: Scott S.

description: Great, tucked away place for a glass (or more) of wine and some bites.  The atmosphere is cozy, but the high ceilings keep it from feeling claustrophobic.  Great service.  Will definitely return.
author: B. Y.

description: Loved this place. Excellent little wine bar tucked in an alley. The have a bocce court as well. The wines were great and the ambiance is everything. I will be going back again wheb i get a chance.
author: Andrew C.

description: Still top of my list as a hidden gem to try out the tasting menu or a specific country / region before a big dinner or a show! It's especially great if you are not hungry enough to eat but want a cozy and intimate place to whisper or a place to enjoy some social chatters in the velvety deco and wine...
author: T L.

description: Excellent wine selection.  Had two great glasses of La Follette and cheese.  Can't beat that cheese plate.  Super warm environment.  Going back with friends on Tuesday.  A must visit for any wine person in the city.
author: Mark G.

description: This wine bar is more homey than trendy and was a very pleasant surprise on my recent trip to San Fran. I felt completely comfortable here as a solo female customer. I had the Riesling flight ($11 for 3 amazing glasses of wine!!) paired with 2 cheeses (La Tur and ... forgot the other one), bread, and the persimmon Celtic chutney. That chutney was to-die-for, and the service was perfect. Wish I could bring the owner home with me and have him set up shop in my basement!
author: Emily R.

description: What is the fascination with this place?  The wine is expensive, the food is meh.  It's right next to my work and many of us were excited to try it.   If you love the douchey, Marina vibe, then this is your downtown home.  Otherwise, skip this unmemorable 'pretty people' hangout and head to Barrique up the street.  The only perk of a wine bar is the selection and low price, of which, they had neither.
author: Jared H.

description:
Yelp led me here while I was on a biz trip to SF and was I thrilled!  The super knowledgeable and really patient staff introduced me, a wine lover with admittedly limited knowledge of the field, to some incredible vino and cheese pairings.  I was surrounded by people who REALLY knew their stuff but wasn't made to feel like a newbie or a loser at all... the place isn't snooty, rather it seems to be eager to welcome new members to the fraternity of wine-lovers.  Perfect.

The tucked-away, cushy chair, cool-and-eclectic-music atmosphere just made the experience one I will never forget. A not-to-be-missed spot if you're a wine lover of any expertise level and happen to find yourself in the Union Square area.
author: Brendan O.

description:
Cute little wine bar located across from Le Colonial.  When I went there recently, I had to smile because I remembered how one Yelper had written that it was like drinking in Grandma's basement parlour.  When I mentioned that, she thought it was "cozy" which seems to be the one word that comes up the most in describing The Hidden Vine.

I liked how it was laid back and wasn't a "scene" kind of place, even for a Friday night.  Personally, I prefer a bit more flash, but all in all, it was a nice place and the service was very friendly.  We had two red wine flights, Italy and Spain, and although they weren't too memorable, they were both reasonably priced with good pours.

I would definitely go back.
author: Roy N.

description:
I better write this before I forget about going here and how good it was. Too late! It's almost a fading memory. 

I do remember several kinds of wine, three flights, some great comparisons, a nice quite setting even though it's so small. I got to try several different kinds of wine, and the little cards on the glass helped. Too bad I can't remember what we had.  OH, we had dessert wine too.  

I remember leaving, bottle in hand. The next thing I remember is waking up the next morning. I don't remember paying, but saw the receipt the next day. How I got home, I'll never know. 

That's all I got ... and I can't wait to go back when I can write a proper review!  Serves me right for not eating much before I went in.  Eat before you go!
author: Michael M.

description: We came primarily for the bocce ball court, which became a fixation after spending a few days at a rental in Napa that had its own court, so this place seemed like a great idea for emulating that experience. The court has a chalkboard to sign up for time, but when we arrived at 9 on a Friday, there was nobody using it. The bar requires spending $100 at the bar for an hour of court time. This was no problem for a group of 4 people. The staff were knowledgeable and helpful and I would say we got some decent deals on some excellent bottles. The appetizer meat and cheese plate was spot on. We didn't have any entrees, although they looked tempting. I am also pleased with the location as Cafe Prague is right next door, which might make a god combination for an evening group excursion.
author: CJ M.

description:
I was not impressed with this place. And I'm a sucker for wine bars. I love wine bars; they're my favorite bars of all time! Yes, it's cute and hidden in the cute neighborhood of Nob Hill/Tender nob, but the service was real crappy.  And quality is important to me.  

It took the server at LEAST 20 minutes to come by our table and ask if we were ready to order.  One of the gals I was with even had to go up to the bar to tell him we were ready to order.  The bar was not all busy either.  

We all had flights of wine (two reds and one white).  One of the red wines was so gross (it tasted like hard liquor), I couldn't even take more than a few sips of it.  I believe it was called the Casalone. Ewww, if you order the red, I would tell the server you do not want this wine. 

Ehhh, i hope to find another cute wine bar in this neighborhood with way better service.
author: Jenny W.

description:
The terms, "cozy" and "intimate" have been used frequently in the reviews, and I can't think of better descriptives for The Hidden Vine.  For a perpetual wine newb like myself, it provided the perfect platform in which to sample various wines.  I hate that it took me so long to check it out.  

Other than the wildly different sets of tables and chairs, it is literally like settling into someone's Victorian-inspired living room.  I can't stress how nice it is to be able to go to a drinking establishment on a weekend, 1. that isn't crowded and stuffy, and 2. are able to hear each other's conversation.

They do offer a food menu of nibblers (cheese, olives, and the like) to go along with their extensive wine menu.  I loved the different flights and head-to-head comparisons.  Not to mention, the prices being more than reasonable.  I only wish there were more glass options available.

Service was timely and informative; I have no complaints.  But between the complicated wine names and regions, more than half the things our server said went right over my head.  He could've been talking out of his ass for all I know, but it sounded like he knew his sh*t.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Really nice little spot that we stumbled upon during our little exploration of downtown/chinatown/north beach. Really good wines, cool samplers and flights, and very knowledgeable and friendly staff. They took the time to explain things to us and let us taste things before we committed to larger portions. We were all feeling pretty toasty when we left. Really comfy environment too. Felt very festively decorated, nice fireplace. It was empty when we went, which was cool too. It was a little pricey, but I think it was inline with similar places, especially considering the location. And for those Bocce enthusiasts, make reservations in advance because I hear it can get competitive.
author: Miguel V.

description: Visiting Sam Francisco for the weekend... I love wine and figured this sounds like the perfect spot. Definitely not! Service is very poor. Felt like I had to beg for a glass. Staff was too busy socializing. Won't be back. Wouldn't recommend
author: Ray H.

description: I used to frequent this place pretty often since it was in between the office and home.  Small, dark and intimate but sometimes too busy.  I always feel like something is missing but maybe it's just me.
author: Suz L.

description: Its a good date spot for drinks or after dinner drinks.  Don't forget to check in and also have your date check in so you can get 50% off your first glass of wine.  Women love cheap fat asses.  Trust me I'm fat.
author: Fatty A.

description:
The Hidden Vine is accessed either via a back alley, or through a quaint hotel, which lends heavily to a noir setting.  Duck in out of a rainy night and dive into a glass.  The quiet and intimate setting will lull you either into good conversation, or conversely, a slumber.

Roundup:
 - Quiet, intimate.
 - Decor is pretentious, but very comfortable. 
 - The space is small, enough for three at the bar, and 20 in the assorted couches and chairs.
 - There is a limited selection of Cabs by the glass, but the quality shiraz and chiantis make up for this.  The menu on their site: http://www.thehiddenvine.com/about.shtml is outdated.  The actual winelist is 2-3 times as long.
author: KyNam D.

description:
This is a little hard to find, but so worth it!

Small, SUPER chill, and cute "cork dorks" behind the bar who will help you pick the perfect wine and the cheese that goes with it.

I came with a group of friends for a drink before dinner, but I could see it as being a really good date place as well. 

So boys......who is taking me to the Hidden Vine?
author: Alicia K.

description: We reserved the Bocce court for an hour saturday night and had a great time. The court is a little slice of brick wall heaven in a city without much brick ... and brick walls mean wind shelter ... The staff brought our wine and flatbread out to the court and it felt luxurious even though it is basically free (just need a minimum order). The flatbread was amazing. Some wines were stronger than others. I wish they would expand their food menu a bit more. The inside is masculine cozy with leather chair and sofas - good date night place.
author: Bridget F.

description: This is a really nice place to come for a quiet glass of wine AND you can play bocce ball. There's a fireplace with a pair of armchairs.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Susan B.

description:
There are two entrances. 

If you enter through the alley you will feel like you are breaking into your Aunt Mildreds living room. Except that your Aunt Mildred is suddenly a bunch of young beautiful wine drinkin' lushes who are here to partay. Don't let the "I'm going to stay at home on a Friday night knitting an afghan" decorating style fool you. 

The front entrance will make you feel like a tourist, since you are entering through a small hotel lobby. You will feel like the sort of tourist who says "Wow, I want to stay at a hotel that has a wine bar decorated like Aunt Mildreds living room, but full of young beautiful wine drinkin' lushes who are here to partay". 

Either way, this place is a good thing. The wine selections are tasty and unique and the staff talk to you as if you are smarter than the average young beautiful wine drinkin' lush. They rotate out particular regions for their flights, so there is always something new to try. Minus one star for not having more wines by the glass, but I hear Aunt Mildred is working on that!
author: Drue C.

description:
Review # 259. Maybe they should change the name to The Out In The Open Vine. 

Believe it or not, it is kinda hidden. You can either enter it from an alley near Le Colonial or through a hotel lobby in which it is located. And it's not the nicest hotel lobby either so I entered the wine bar with a bit of trepidation. Which dissipated instantly. It's old school gorgeous in there. Very warm and inviting. We sat in some of the most comfortable chairs. The kind that you just kinda fall into. 

We were there early and had the whole joint to ourselves for a bit. The waiter/ sommelier took his time going over the menu with us and he was incredibly knowledgeable. It almost felt like a mini-class on wines and regions. I enjoyed this immensely. 

Wine was ordered. A flight for the lady. A red for myself. I expressed my likes: reds, earthy, bold. The wine delivered was just what I wanted. The three glasses in the flights came with name tags on the bottom so you could distinguish between each. Fantastic idea. More wine bars should do this. 

So the spot was empty and lo and behold, in walks a group of sorority girls who decide to take up the table next to us for their seven year reunion. Every single chair/table was empty and they sit next to the couple in the corner involved in a quiet intimate discussion. Who does that? Therefore we had to overcome their high pitched yelping about beemers and their boyfriends Chad til we left.... this is why I don't own a gun. 

They say the music soothes the savage beast and they are right, if it wasn't for Wilco playing over the speakers their reunion would have had a different outcome. It wasn't just the music, it was the wine and the fantastic cheese selections that came with ample amounts of bread and the olives which were finger-licking tasty. 

My only complaint was that I puled an amateur move in drinking wine. I went from bold to light for my second glass. I zigged when I should have zagged. That was completely my fault and I don't hold our waiter responsible.... although he should have scoffed at me like a true oenophile and maybe I would have made a better choice. But what would a night of drinking be without poor decision making??
author: Bucky K.

description: Beautiful place. Difficult to discover, but once you're inside, you won't regret it. The ambiance alone is worth the pricey wine, but with a relatively good selection, I can't imagine ever having a bad time here. Throw on a button-down shirt, grab a friend, and go have a good time in a place you'd expect to find in San Francisco!
author: Cameron G.

description:
It's Hidden, alright. But that doesn't stop this little underground lair of grape-crushed goodness from being packed with the after-work crew. Boys, this is a goldmine of single women in the late-20s to mid-30s range. If you're a successfulish, youngish guy looking to hook it up by 9 p.m. on a weeknight, this may very well be the place for you. 

Great wine list, excellent cheese plate, and knowledgeable wine folks make this an awesome place for a quiet glass or flight with friends. The owners are an awesome couple and they have  very lovingly built their business up since opening a few years ago. Hidden Vine is kind of a cross between Lovejoy's Tearoom and Yield wine bar, decor-wise. They've done away with a lot of the schlocky decorative items that were there when they first opened (think plastic flowers) but some schlock remains, toned down by the shadowy, romantic lighting.

I prefer Cav and Biron only because I they're more my scene- more industrial, less victorian front room. Hidden Vine is a great wine bar for when you want to feel like you're drinking at home without really drinking at home. I personally like to drink wine at my own home, but I'm sure we'll be back again soon. It's right across the alley from Le Colonial, making it a great place to hit post-dinner.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Its a nook.  I love nooks.  They are cozy and comfy and you always want to end up back in that same little nook.  Like when cuddling with someone at night, I always end up in their chest/arm nook, this might be my wine bar equivalent.  Its attached to the Fitzgerald hotel, but if you enter off of Cosmo Place, you walk down stairs into this cute little room with couches set up all intimate like, and a tiny little counter at the bar for 3.  That is where we sat.

A girlfriend of mine recently got a job bartending here, and so two of us dropped in to say hi last night.  The pinot-syrah blend i had was perfectly light, and my friends zinfandel was just what she wanted as well.  We didn't order any food, but they do have a great little cheese platter, in addition to other munchies if you want a nibble.

And mad props (yes, i said mad props), to the staff there.  Not only are they knowledgeable and approachable, and kind, but they wash EVERY dish by hand!  That's right, no dishwasher to spot their wine glasses.  Nope.  Every cheese plate, every wine glass gets their attention.  Now that's dedication.
author: Lauren F.

description:
You have to check this place out just because its address starts with 1/2! 

What a hidden little gem in the middle of the hustle -- when we walked into the basement bar at 5 PM on a Friday, we were the second party to arrive. It did not take long for all tables to fill out but at no point in the evening was it crowded.  

The space is very cozy, with low ceilings, carpets, and couches. The wine list is worthy of such a place -- has both very reasonably priced pleasers as well as more spendy choices. They also have some featured flights as well as comparison flights (2 half-glasses of similar wines for compare-and-contrast exercise). A small cheese/appetizer menu is also available.  A perfect spot to either get together with your friends and read a book with a nice glass of port.

Their bathroom is located back in the hotel lobby -- the small space has a suspicious uncovered window right by the toilet. Fear not -- someone such as myself has examined the situation and is ready to report back!  The window leads into one of the narrowest wells between the two buildings with no other windows facing it on the same level -- so you can rest assured of your restroom privacy!

And yes, bathroom situation is important when reviewing a bar ;-)
author: Gina M.

description:
Doctors say that one (1) glass of red wine per day, is good for your heart. Well, I think that maybe two glasses, a tasting flight & some yummy cheeses is EVEN better. The Hidden Vine was my first wine bar experience in San Francisco. I recently made the resolution to get back into wines, something I enjoyed very much when I worked in fine dining in San Diego.

It was actually tucked away in an alley, I would have never known it existed if not for the internets. There's a front entrance through the hotel, which coincidentally could be very nice if you are 'too drunk to drive, ride, walk, whatever'.

They have a very extensive selection of wines, both California & European, and aren't snobby in the way the menu is presented. They actually list the wines & give some general detail as to what you'll get--a definite plus if you are new or have been out of the game for awhile.

The staff is hard-working & very courteous, when I mentioned our party would be growing in size they were very helpful in accommodating us. Our server explained the tasting flights in depth--and had each 2oz tasting tagged with the name & year. And of course...she reminded that we were to taste from left to right for the proper experience.

I felt very cozy & comfortable here, even though it was crowded...the layout of the bar was just about right.

Minus one star because they should have more wines by the glass.

On a side note, please don't believe what AK says about it being a goldmine...She has no clue what she is talking about. It's all dudes, all-the-time.  ;-)
author: matt m.

description: I came here for my friends birthday because she had a LivingSocial deal to use.  Or we tried to.  The place was closed.  No note about renovations, moving, anything.  We checked their website and there was nothing informing there either.  We obviously had to go somewhere else.  When she emailed them to see if they had moved or reopened she never got a response.  Hopefully information will surface about what's going on and she can finally use her certificate.
author: Jen K.

description:
The Hidden Vine is, in fact, hidden; It's in the back of the lobby of a nondescript hotel in nob hill. There's only a small sign on the building's facade. 

The inside feels like someone's living room; lots of couches and small tables, paintings and a non-functioning fireplace and mantle. It gets crowded and warm here in the evenings but it wasn't really stuffy considering how many people were in the room. I felt a little more comfortable here than I did at Hotel Biron, maybe it's just me though. 

The menu features samples of the month's featured region or variety grouped in three two-ounce servings or two half-glasses, and a collection of around 60 different wines grouped by color and character. Only a dozen or so of the regular selections are available by the glass, running ten to twelve dollars on average. 

The staff is attentive and knowledgeable. And they can more or less fly around a tiny bar and a crowded room without spilling wine on anyone, or at least anyone at our table.

It was here that AK and I concieved of the wine dive bar: dark with basic furniture, basic Trader Joe's wines for a buck or two per glass, punk rock and tom waits on the jukebox, a mechanical bull, porn video games, and a picture booth. I'm not an expert on these things but I think this could be huge.

I'm not really the wine bar type. I just think The Hidden Vine could have used a mechanical bull or at least a foosball table.

And there's another reason for you guys to check this place out but I promised another member of our party that I wouldn't say anything.
author: matthew r.

description: Great place hidden in the back of a hotel lobby. Wines and cheese are well priced. Good wine selection. Quiet and somewhat secluded - couches make it comfy and casual. Music depends on the bartender (they use their ipods).
author: R C.

description:
I'd heard about what a great date spot this is, so I thought I'd see this place for the first time with a first date. 

I like my bars the way I like my women -- challenging -- and I appreciate how easy it is to miss from the street. In fact, this place seems somehow more surreptitious than the nearby Bourbon and Branch. I could see a lot of extramarital affairs happening here. (And somehow, I mean that as a compliment.)

All I had was one glass, which I liked, so I can't speak to the quality of booze here. The decor is definitely on the cutesy side, but for what this bar is going for it pulls it off well. No need to get closer to have a conversation here -- it was so quiet I could hear every glass clink in the joint. 

I guess I can only fault Hidden Vine for being so cozy that I'd never bring a guy friend here, lest our testosterone level drop to Oprah-watching levels. And it's no place to meet new people. But the bar made it easy for my date and I to corrupt each other, so I'm a believer.
author: Greg K.

description:
Cozy intimate place for friends or a date. I'm not a wine connisier but I did enjoy the wines that were served. The woman who served our group, Sara,  very helpful and friendly and when it came to my turn to pick a bottle, Sara was very patient. She used her detective skills to determine what I like and what I should drink...It helped that she was adept at being a sommelier, yet not elitist. She kept telling me not to be intimidated, "Wine is just a beverage..."  

Needless to say our group had a great time there, we didn't leave till 3am.
author: Alvin C.

description:
Itty Bitty Little place I probably would have never found were it not for Yelp.

I don't really drink, so I never know what to order, but the friendly people behind the bar here suggested some yummy white wine and I was set for the hour or so I hung out here.

Great place!
author: Richard T.

description: This is my new favorite wine bar. It is so dark, warm, and cozy inside. Big wooden beams, overstuffed chairs, and great wine list. Plus, they have bocce outside! Love that it is hidden down an alley, too.
author: Heather M.

description:
Popped my Hidden Vine cherry last night, and like most cherry popping experiences, I was left thinking, "What's the big deal?  I definitely should have done this long ago."

The waitress/sommelier was really great and knew a metric shitton about wine.  Most of the time I was just nodding my head, pretending I knew what she was talking about.  I did a tasting flight of three South African wines, and they were all fantastic.

Two very enthusiastic thumbs up; fine family fun.
author: Casey S.

description: I've been hearing a lot about this place, mostly on Yelp, so finally had the chance to visit. Hidden is right, you have to go down some stairs on Cosmo Place to enter the intimate room. I went on a Thursday, so the place was pretty busy, but still relatively easy to secure a nice seat. Our waitress was really cool, and the wine menu had a great selection to choose from, which obviously helps if you're a wine bar! This is definitely a great place to meet up with friends after work (on some nights they also lay out a thoughtful cracker and cheese spread that pairs nicely with almost any wine).
author: Nish N.

description:
In a city full of bars that are too trendy, too expensive or just trying too hard this tiny slice of happiness is probably more than any of us deserve.  If you haven't been, what is wrong with you?  If you have been I bet you wish you were there right now!

The owners, Angela & Dave, know enough about wines to be pretentious but the only snobbery you will encounter at the hidden vine are lazy spy's stealing the wine list for their own bars and restaurants.  Angela and Dave will take the time to tell you everything about each wine if you ask and sometimes even when you don't.  

The service is always excellent and occasionally expeditious.  The cheese, duck breast, and truffles plates always compliment the wines so give them a try.  You can always find something new because the menu is always changing with a new region to explore every month.
author: Glenn P.

description:
A group of us from work had a really fun time here. They have a big chef's table up in the front which probably seats 12 people. We arrived early and learned that you can pay to reserve the table, but nobody had for that night so we were lucky and took it over. Service was incredibly accommodating. They switched servers on us a few times, but all were knowledgeable about the wines and seemed to be communicating well because subsequent servers knew what we had ordered previously. Fantastic wine selection by the glass! Seven of us were drinking for four hours straight and not a disappointing pour the entire time. The servers' recommendations were really spot on. We also ordered almost everything off the food menu. I like that they had substantial items on the menu.
