None of it is "dinner" but between sliders, pizzas and charcuterie, we all left very satisfied. I wasn't a fan of the crab slider, but pork and beef were excellent, as were the pates, pickes, charcuterie and cheeses. There was also a nice beet and pear salad on the menu that disappeared very quickly.

Food and wine is pricey, but quality matches and the atmosphere is perfect. 

Vibe is super cozy. Place filled up shortly after 5p and remained full, but not overly packed, the entire time we were there. Background music was fun and eclectic (thank you for playing Pixies!). It's a dark space, so better for cozy winter days or late night adventures.

And after four glasses of wine, bocce is REALLY fun! Thanks Hidden Vine. We'll be back.
author: Arkay K.

description: A short list of things I like. Wine. Games.  When the two can be done together I am a happy person. Love that you can play Bocce and drink a nice glass of wine while doing so. I also love that you can reserve the Bocce for an hour at a time.  Huge fan.
author: douglas B.

description:
Best wine bar in San Francisco. I wrote that for one of the weeklies a few years ago, but they failed to tell me I couldn't choose the same place that had won the year before, and so didn't run my write-up.

Though I haven't been here alone with my special girl, it has to be in the top 5 romantic places to be in the city (Top of the Mark being No. 1).

Besides the best atmosphere you can ask for, with low lighting, comfortable seating, and intimacy without being forced to join in your neighbor's conversation, there's the wine list.

Hidden Vine thrives on letting you taste as well as learn wines. The front page of the menu is filled with flights and side-by-side comparisons. For the head-to-heads, you're served glasses with generous pours and labels facing down. Sorry, but anything conducive to my playing a game solo is a winner in my book.

So ...

Take a group of friends wanting to learn more about wines by tasting them in a pleasant atmosphere. Or take your special someone down the steps from Cosmo Alley (where, just a few steps down, you'll find the famed Le Colonial) and stake out a cushioned cubby hole of your own. Drink down your wine and remember that you're in one of the best places to do what you're doing, in one of the best cities for the same.
author: Jeff H.

description: The location of this place fits it's name.  It's hidden in an alleyway but once there, you'll love the atmosphere.  Great wine selection and they have good appetizers to compliment their wine selection.   The servers were nice and knowledgeable about the wines they served.  Most wine places are snobby but this place was more laid back and welcoming.  I'll be back for more.  =)
author: Carlos A.

description:
When one of my friends asked me to meet her for post-work libations one evening, I kept thinking to myself, "She must be bringing me here to scope the place out for an upcoming date." The speakeasy-like cozy atmosphere and lighting would flatter anyone and make them fall in love. Even though I wasn't on a date, I enjoyed myself. The service was amazing. I arrived early and it was cold so I decided to steal a nook to wait for my friend, completely hidden from view upon entering. He kept an eye out for my friend as I waited gingerly by myself in the dark. Aside from that, there was cheese, charcuterie, and olive platters along with bread that you help yourself to while you tasted the wine. 

I had the European flight tasting, consisted of three types of wine. One from Italy, one from Spain, and one from somewhere I can't recall. I am not a wine snob by any means, but I know what I like when it goes in my mouth. All three of the wines were really good, but the last one was so complex that each sip tasted completely different. As the evening came to a close, we informed a waitress, who turned out to be an owner of the place, that we loved one of the wines. She brought out a Californian version of it on the house since we enjoyed it so much. She also suggested places to purchase the wine that we so dearly enjoyed. And they have the wines with handwritten coasters so you can take them home! 

Sidenote: the place has a monthly change on their tastings, so I guess I'll have to go back every month. Perhaps with a cute date next time.
author: Wing L.

description:
I recently checked out Hidden Vine after reading about the wine, atmosphere and music (specifically, Raoul mentioning that they played B Movie, the Smiths, etc.), and while there was no B Movie or Smiths to be heard the night I went, the wine and atmosphere exceeded my expectations!

While I didn't commit the full details of the wines I had to memory, they were two reds, a Cabernet Sauvignon from California and a Fetish 'Playmates' SMG from Australia (gotta love that second name!). While the California Cab was great, the Australian wine was even better, and had a subtly sweet, berry-like finish.

As mentioned in all the other reviews, this place feels like someone's living room or den and would be a great place to chill on a quiet evening...in fact, I noticed that several people came alone towards the end of the night just to enjoy a glass (or flight) of their faves.

My girlfriend ordered a two-cheese plate, and while not everything she ordered was to my taste, the Cowgirl Creamery 'Mt. Tam' cheese, bread and dried blueberries were fantastic. She mentioned that their cheese portions were quite generous for the price which sounds like a good thing to me.

Parking is tough in this neighborhood, but The Hidden Vine is definitely worth checking out, especially if you wish to indulge in your Fetish...yeah, baby!
author: Art D.

description:
Yep.

This is one of those places that you go to as a visitor and leave bummed you don't live there.

I adored the Hidden Vine. It was so cute and cozy and made me feel like I should have been smoking a cigar in a satin jacket or something. Very old school vibe but with a comfortable up to date flair. 

Then there was the wine, I enjoyed the yummiest glasses of Zin here that was seriously the best one out of 7 days of bar and restaurant hopping. And I am a snooty wino, so that is saying alot. I'm also a bit bad on the memory this week so of course I can't for the life of me remember what the hell it was called, but man o man, yummay!

The staff was also really nice and seemed like they knew their stuff pretty well. Obviously I would go back again, I just have to wait til Yelp needs me to come back up to SF again *hint hint hint*
author: Stephy S.

description:
My girlfriend and I are wine whores, and I mean that in the nicest possible way. When we go to Napa, Sonoma, Mendecino, Russian River, Placerville, jesus everywhere we drop all our stupid money on awesome wines. Well, mostly awesome, usually the latter wines are bought because we're drunk (i.e. "Why in the name of all that is holy did we buy a case of Scharffenberger Sparkling Wine yesterday?").

That said, it's nice to go a place like Craig and Angela's The Hidden Vine and spend money on good wine that already been verified as good wine by people who tasted it while they were sober. The atmosphere is super cozy and friendly, and the little snacks make it possible to stay here from open to close, or at least until the vino catches up with the last bit of awake in your cerebral cortex.
author: Tal K.

description:
I had my fifth experience here this week and every one of them has been perfect.

I know I'm just joining in the chorus here but it really is *the* ideal wine bar. Walking down the stairs you feel as though you're entering somebody's cozy living room. I've always felt completely at home here. The staff (owners? it always seems to be the same guys) are very knowledgeable about the wines but not pretentious in the least. .

Oh, and the smoked duck. Essential.

Everything a wine bar should be.
author: Joe D.

description:
Hidden Vine rules. I've been meaning to check this place out since I first discovered Yelp over two years ago. I finally got around to stopping in last weekend and I'm sad I didn't come here sooner. 

The first thing I noticed was the super relaxed vibe inside. It's almost like I was in my own living room. I sprawled out on one of the plush couches and just kicked back. Eventually I got around to ordering some wine and cheese. 

Every month they do a flight from a different region so I went with the red wine flight from Lebanon and Israel. It was really cool to try wine from such an exotic place -- and it was really good too. I drank it along with some Humboldt Fog cheese which is ridiculously good. Overall, it was a fun and relaxing experience and I'll be coming back soon with some friends that I want to impress.
author: Aaron V.

description:
This venue should actually be named "The Hidden Gem." Oh how I love this place. Through a small door on Cosmo place, you go down stairs and enter this little den with a candle-lit fireplace, and couches. The staff is one of the friendlier staffs I have come upon in San Francisco. They were unpretentious and enthusiasticly welcoming. We ordered a bottle of the J Brut Rose. Now this bottle is the stuff my dreams are made of. It was so perfect. In honor of my friend's birthday, the staff brought out a small plate of raspberry chocolate and hazelnut truffles to go with our wine. YUM YUM. 

New go-to spot for Miss Anna!
author: Anna S.

description:
Was brought to this out of the way location by someone I used to know, so it holds special meaning to me.  The main entrance opens into a narrow staircase that leads to a quaint and inviting room.  It's not that big, and depending on the night of the week, it can actually feel a little crowded.  Luckily, most of the times, we were 1 couple out of a handful.  Although I'm not much of a drinker, and much less, a wine drinker, the libations were rather good.  The appetizers were also typical of a wine bar: cheese and assorted meats.  The coziest looking area, which is an alcove near the stairs, is actually not that comfortable.  For some reason, the bench they installed is kinda harsh on the back and not matter what position we tried, it didn't help.  Maybe a better seat cushion and extra pillows.

Still, one day I'll go back...
author: Jaime J.

description:
Wow!  What a find in San Francisco!

Since we just opened our own wine shop only 4 months ago, we took a weekend for some much needed rest and also "research."  We knew we were staying in San Francisco and wanted to find a local wine bar walking distance from our hotel.  Thanks to YELP, we found The Hidden Vine!  Only a couple of blocks from our hotel, we walked to this really amazing wine bar.

It was a busy Thursday night, and every seat was filled.  This is not a problem for us, since it means "good business" for them.  It is NEVER a bad thing to be busy, especially when everyone is so welcoming and kind.  Thanks to a nice patron, he offered his two seats so we could sit down.  We quickly found out we had much in common since he was also in the wine industry and we all ended up sitting together and sharing a bottle of wine (Sea Smoke "Botella" Pinot Noir ... enjoy it while it's still available!).

One of the owners, Angela came around while greeting and checking on all the patrons.  She was amazing and we complimented her and her husband on their impressive business.  She also made sure we tried a sneak preview of Ceja Vineyards "Dulce Beso" (Angela, thank you for being so generous.)  

We look forward to visiting The Hidden Vine every time we visit San Francisco and are recommending it to ALL our own customers to do the same.  

We can now see why The Hidden Vine has so many amazing reviews!
author: Lisa C.

description:
Thank you my fellow Yelpers for helping me discover this place! I strongly suggest taking Bart (about a 7 minute walk from the Powell Station) because once you taste the wines here, you just cant stop drinking!!! My friend and I came here and was immediatly capitvated by the ambiance...Low lit room, red velvet chairs.. This place is for the Grown and Sexy! We started off with the flight wines, I remember one of them being the Fetish 'Playmates' SMG from Australia and it was delicious..We especially liked  the Kathryn Kennedy 'Lateral' Bordeaux so much that we ordered 2 bottles of it! No wine would be complete without cheese so we got the Cowgirl Creamery and the Emmi Cave-aged Gruyre (recommended by the friendly and well informed staff) the cheese came with baguettes, dried fruits, and Chutney... Damn that was some good cheese!!!
Hidden Vine... I will see you next weekend!
author: Dwight C.

description:
This place is so San Francisco. Admittedly, I am no expert on the nightlife in SF. But my take based on my limited exposure is that people around here like things a little more low key...class without the glitz and glamour. We're not about L.A. or Vegas. 

Hidden Vine epitomizes that kind of laid back style of good times. If you go past the hotel and make a left around the corner and head down the little alleyway to the valet parking behind the building, you'll find the long staircase that leads down to this plush find. It's like walking into someone's living room in an old Victorian. Dark furniture, ambiant light, comfy chairs...Old World charm, but sexy and romantic at the same time. 

If you go past nine on a weekend, it might be standing room only, but it's still a nice place to hang out with a choice glass of wine in hand. The list is pretty good with flights and wines by the glass.
author: Virg Y.

description:
The most aptly named spot in the city, it is hidden and they serve wine.  Completely, utterly, unpretentious, no attitude, not trendy, just warm and comfortable and dark.  Extremely carpeted.  The selection is wide, even for a wine bar, and it is priced to move: more than half the bottles are $27 to $45, it is all interesting stuff, and the staff knows their wine.  Some simple but hearty and delicious cheese and meat plates and they do not skimp.  One of the best places in town for a sit and talk, writing the next great american novel on your laptop, or a brief rest from the strains of urban living.

4 stars, but I'll give one more because they deserve it.
author: Gil S.

description:
There's no place like home...and The Hidden Vine feels a lot like home.  Although I have been here many times, it keeps pulling me back in. My own experiences here have included rowdiness after dinner with a group, crunk heart to hearts with girlfriends and my first date with the bf.

After visiting a couple other classy wine joints, I have come to the determination that this is my fave wine bar in the city.  The people who work here are knowledgeable yet unpretentious.  They leave you alone to enjoy your wine instead of rushing you through the experience.  

Although it has been "unhidden" for awhile now,  I always manage to find a place to sit at The Hidden Vine.  Best of all are the ever changing flights of wine that they offer.  Last weekend, I tried the Santa Barbara reds which were very different yet all DELICIOUS.  Flights are best enjoyed with a cheese plate which is the only food offered and mighty tasty.  

How awesome would it be to move in here?  Then, it really would be my *actual* home.  Nah, they have already given me enough.  I can't ask the Hidden Vine gods for more.
author: Rosie F.

description:
Prosecco for $20.

Intimate setting.

"Shake it off" by Mariah was playing. 

The girls and I flirted with the bartendar. 

Whats not to love hmmm?
author: Mimi S.

description:
In the same alley as Le Colonial is a little door, leading down the stairs into a cute little wine bar that looks like a bed and breakfast with out the bed and breakfast. Small seating area for gathering with friends, and then a small bar area. Tiny little place but just the perfect tucked away secret spot. Of course it's a secret spot on Yelp so it's not really a secret. But still while I was there, it felt special. 

Nice offering of wines and champagnes and some light food like cheese, meats and desserts. The staff is super friendly and knew their inventory and didn't make the little wine innocent like me feel lost looking at the menu. 

Had I not had plans to meet someone at Le Colonial, I would have stayed here all night.
author: Denise B.

description:
Stumbled across this place while trying to avoid Le Colonial and was impressed not only by the wine list but by the knowledgeable servers.  Interesting decor...sort of a 1960s English feel to it.  Very affordable and a nice selection of wines by the glass.  And if you have a glass and buy the bottle, they'll knock a few bucks off the bottle you buy.  Cool little couches and nooks make it a good place for a glass of wine after a drink.  

For that area, it's either get a nice glass of wine here or get in line and fight off the cougars at Redwood Room.  Up to you.
author: Geoff K.

description: I feel kind of like Ebenezer Scrooge here, but I just don't really get it. I'm no wine expert but I do like wine bars--the Press Club (yeah, I know, they hate being called a wine bar), Yield, Hotel Biron, Que Syrah all come to mind. But I just felt strange here. Like I had stumbled into the dining room of an English bed and breakfast at the wrong hour and forgot to wear chintz. (And I lived in England for too long to mean "English bed and breakfast" as a compliment).
author: Susan S.

description:
It was my 25th birthday.  I was supposed to meet a few friends at The Hidden Vine to celebrate, and riding high on the fact that earlier in the day a college kid had asked for my number, I showed up a little early.  I sat down on the cushy sofa in the corner, chatted with the super-friendly owner/bartendress and ordered a generously poured Red at her recommendation, and kept myself occupied building houses out of proscuitto.  And they were impressively structurally sound houses, given that they were made out of glorified lunch meat.

So as I'm sipping and constructing, an older, obviously inebriated gentleman walked in and sat down next to a group of 20-somethings at the bar.  I wasn't too far away, so I caught bits and pieces of their conversation.  He made baudy jokes; they laughed, and I tried to hide my smirks.  I guess I did a pretty poor job of that, though, as he caught my eye.  What follows is verbatim:

"HELLO young lady, and what brings you here all alone tonight?"

"Oh, I'm just having a glass of wine before my friends arrive."

"Really?  I'm drinking scotch.  SCOTCH!  It's God's water.  You've got nice breasts.  How would you like to [blank] on my [blank] while I put my [blank] in your [blank]?  I'll give you $100."

For the sake of propriety, I've omitted several key words.  I'm sure you can figure out the gist, however.  The 20-somethings fell silent as I thanked the gentleman for his offer and regretfully declined.  He soon left, perhaps in search of a more receptive young lady.

So can I promise that you'll get propositioned at The Hidden Vine?  No.  But try it anyway, you might catch a lucky break.
author: Jess T.

description:
I guess I'll have to try it again.  I think it was quite stuffy and pretentious actually.  I felt very uncomfortable.  We had one beer and took off.

I may have been paranoid because I was already a little tipsy though.
author: Krista L.

description:
It's hidden, but not forbidden!  Super cute hand out that is great for an after dinner glass or flight of wine.  The crowd is pretty mellow, so it is a nice place to take a date.  I love the little nooks and privacy of the seating arrangement.

The owners are not pompous or pretentious; pretty hard to find at wine bars.  They are also more than happy to explain the wine, and they do a great job at describing the flavors in terms that us "normal" wine drinkers can understand.
author: Lulu B.

description:
Ok, so the place already has 200something reviews but here's another one. This place was on my list for a while and I finally had the chance to check it out. So it feels kinda like the Cheers of the wine world. It looks like someone's house (but at that kind of perfect lighting that makes everyone look beautiful). So someone's sophisticated library then. You know, kind of a big deal. Rich mohagany and leather bound books and all.

We went on Thursday night, which is cheese night, which is lovely. They had put out a small selection of gouda, manchego, some meats, olives and bread to munch on (free!)

We ordered the European flight, which was uhhhhhhmaaaaaazing... For you winos out there :) this was the first time I got to finally try Bera, a hard to find wine with the Nabiolo grape. So complex. So amazing. The owner brought us over a Nabiolo wine from California too so that we could compare and contrast. You could definitely taste that CA earthiness/soil/mineraly bite that most CA wines have while the Italian Bera was really deep and full bodied. Interesting grape though since almost every sip of the wine tasted different.

The two owners are charming--really down to earth and friendly. They tell you about the wines in an approachable and interesting way. Not in a pretentious, "the-fact-that-i-even-have-to-tell-you-this-makes-me-want-to-throw-a-box-of-1.99-almaden-white-at-you" kind of way at all.

It's a good place to take a cozy group of friends as well as just a date. I like versatility :)
author: verna b.

description: Really enjoyed this place. It's a bit hidden but at night this part of the city is just beautiful because the financial district is all lite up but not as busy and bustling as it is during the day. I was told this place gets pretty busy on weekends so not sure if I'd want to go when it was busy but on a Wednesday night it was great. Lots of cozy seating and a great environment for good conversation. The music was all 60s which is some of my favorite so I loved it. However our first waiter was a bit pushy and seemed like she just wanted us to hurry up and order because she came back several times in the range of a few minutes. The male waiter that took over for her though was very friendly so that made it more enjoyable. Overall I would say this place is great for dates or catching up with close friends, definitely go with people you can have good conversation with because that's what it's designed for.
author: Grace P.

description: Sat in front of the fire place and that was nice..The cheese platter for 30 $ with OKIsh bread was not impressive..I have definitely tried better ones..my company was not great and that may have affected the overall experience..The drinks were nice..So overall 3 stars only.
author: A S.

description:
184th Review.  Have to say I love this place.  

Had dinner with a friend and "accidentally" walked by this wine bar.  We were on our way to the Le Colonial.  It looked so quaint from the outside that we just had to go and check it out ourselves.  

I love the ambiance and the warmth of this charming little wine bar.  I was instantly drawn to the relaxed atmosphere and the crowd was so unpretentious and fun.  Interesting wine selection (this month they are featuring Chile).  

We had no idea that this wine bar existed but now this is definitely another place that we will go back again just to relax and unwind.  

Great job YELPERS for the great reviews.  You guys are right on with your feedbacks.
author: Gin H.

description:
Tucked away in a little alley off of Taylor, this subterranean vine is truly hidden. This is good, 'cos it keeps the flow of riff-raff to a merciful minimum, and you can always find a cozy spot to nestle into.

Speaking of riff-raff,  a couple nights ago while enjoying a nice glass and good company, a Bachelor "party" came in and sat next to us. This party was complete with loud, boisterous, bull-in-china-shop boys + naked blowup dolls, etc.  Yup. The woman in the couple seated on the other side of them looked like she was going to "tears into burst".  Thankfully, they figgered out this wasn't their speed and moved on. 

The service is great and friendly, almost bordering on too friendly, but not in that get-away-from-me kinda way.  The wine selection includes a broad selection of local vintages and a handful of foreign ones. 5 solid stars!
author: I. O.

description:
*************** 3 1/2 Stars *****************
I finally, FINALLY made it to the Hidden Vine Saturday night.  Definitely must arrive at a decent hour to grab a seat, since the seating is limited and once you're seated (depending on the seat you're in) comfort will set in and you will R.E.L.A.X., well at least we did.  We grabbed the two red cushioned seats at the foot of the stairs and WOW those are quite comfortable...too comfortable, especially since it was really warm down there.  Now i don't know if it's always that warm...so be advised.

The service appears to be nice....except perhaps for the bald bartender who was not very nice...initially we were sitting at the bar and he saw us and just said "someone will be with you..." so he continues to dry wine glasses, while the other servers are pouring wine...few minutes go by and he's still drying glasses and no one acknowledges us...finally he just said "y'know what you want..."

Nice wine bar...great selection...probably will return, maybe baldy was just having a bad night....besides those seats are soooo comfy!!!
author: Karen B.

description:
I hope the rumors about this place closing down isn't true. Even though wine bars are sprouting up all over SF, I really like this place. It's dark and comfortable. The music is GREAT and the people are cool and friendly. They aren't shy on their pour and they have a great selection. 

We also went with a charcuterie platter and cheese platter. I discovered how fucking awesome a cow's milk truffle cheese is. Can't stop eating it now.
author: Jen D.

description: This place is great! Nice and intimate, with an excellent wine selection. Not the cheapest place in the world, but I guess I wouldn't expect it to be. The place is great to meet up with a group or to just have a great one on one conversation. The place can be packed and you still get a good sense of privacy. The service has always been very good as well. I highly recommend The Hidden Vine!
author: Michael H.

description:
What a perfect idea for a wine bar. I walked in and the place smelled like wine in a way I'd expect an opium den to smell like opium. It is essentially a tiny room with a tiny bar that somehow manages to fit several tables together in a very spaceous arrangement that doesnt make it cramped at all. It had this bohemian innocence that would have reminded me of Paris, if I had ever been there.

We orded the southern italian flight and got to taste some great wine. Our favorites among the whites were the greco and the fiona, and amongst the red we liked the dragone rosso. I'm not really into wine so I won't go into them because I'm sure I'll get schooled by someone who takes it much more seriously than me.

We really enjoyed the cheeses as well. Our favorite was the Cypress Grove goat cheese, that came with fig chutney and some bread. Damnit, just writing about it makes me want to go back there and get some more. It reminded me of the goat cheese appetizer at Baraka, it had the same complementary flavors. It's really good. Check it out.

Overall a great time. A perfect happy hour spot to pick to catch up on the times with an old friend, or kick off a romantic date with a special someone.

UPDATE: If you find yourself here and looking for an amazing glass of wine, get the Sequoia cabernet. Its a hefty $17/glass but it by far my favorite wine there and totally worth it in my opinion. If you get a glass of this wine and not like it, then I will personally give you $17... in pennies.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
The Hidden Vine. Very cozy and warm. As we walked down the stairs I notice everyone chillin and conversating and drinking, enjoying their wine. We approached the bar/counter and the bartender gave us a menu of wine list, I was waiting to hear the specials....man there was no many differ wine....so to make it easy I told the bartender what sort of red I enjoy tastying and she hoocked me up with something very nice.....I like this place.....
One thing, the menu wine list is a bite over whelming.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: Great date night or late night place with a girlfriend. Wine is great. Chocolate truffles and prosciutto/crostini app were both amazing. Wine great.
author: Rachel P.

description:
Anywhere that serves a wonderful cheese plate, has a large wine selection, McQuade's Celtic Chutney (and atmosphere to boot) I am in!!

This place is a "hidden" gem. I love the dark and quiet room buried beneath a hotel. When I went Danielle G. and I sampled the white wine flight and it was very good. Each glass comes with a ring around it with the name of the wine and the region it is from. Very tasty and very informative! This is a perfect place to go for a quiet and relaxing night. 

As mentioned before, the Celtic Chutney is amazing and reason enough to give it a try.
author: Natalie N.

description:
My wife and I found this place by accident after eating at the Sushi place nextdoor. You have to love a place whose address is 1/2 Cosmo Place. I want a fraction in my address. 

First off, this place has a speak-easy sort of location, since it is down a back alley. next, you start to question what this place really is once you go down the steep stairs.  You feel like you're going into someone's garden apartment. But once you get down into the main room that is the Hidden Vine, it looks like someone's very cool finished game room, after the TV show "trading spaces" got done with it. They've got a mix of different style chairs, all very comfortable in little sitting areas.  My favorite spot is where my wife and I sat: in an ~ 8'- x 6' recess in one of the walls that has a lounge chair on the open end, and a bench back by the wall. 

I enjoy wine, but don't know a lot about it, and I was not intimidated by their wine list.  They had an Austrian Seasonal Sampler at that time, and we're still looking for an Austrian St. Laurent wine that we had (very modern looking label, using polka dots in the design).  If that rings a bell with anyone, please drop me a line. 

I had the smoked duck breast as well, and it was very good.  This place is worth searching out.
author: Jon B.

description: Went here for the first time for a friend's birthday party over the weekend.  Cute inside, nice ambiance, decent wine list.  But the service was disappointing.  One of the bartenders was rude to me (when I asked for a glass of water -- god forbid!), and another one of their waitstaff tried to shush our friend when she was making an announcement to our large group that we were moving on to another bar.  (Note: the reason we were leaving was because it was midnight and Hidden Vine was closing.)  Really?  Was that necessary?  How about a little gratitude for all of the business my friend brought you with her big birthday party that night?  Admittedly, I'm hypersensitive to bad service.  But I just felt put off by the way the staff treated us.
author: Kerri W.

description:
This place obviously doesn't need my vote, but it's so perfect.  I loved it so much that I went back again the next day!

Did you know that Fridays are 20% off a bottle nights?!  Score!
author: Wendy M.

description: I kind of don't want any more people to figure this place out.  Tucked away in an unsuspecting alley, once you walk in off the street you are in a lovely space with interesting wines and a great cheese plate.  Good for both a romantic date or catching up with friends.
author: e w.

description:
Slightly stuffy english sitting room environs make the hidden vine one of the most comfortable and comforting wine bars in the city. If you are looking for somewhere unpretentious to take an old friend or your Mama, I can hardly think of a better place. The wine list is great, as is the enthusiasm of the owners, and the charcuterie plate could feed a third world clan. 
Yes, the hidden vine is a gem, though a frumpy one.
author: Stellah D.

description:
Only go if:
-You are prepared for a VERY chill night;
-You are in a group of four or less or you are on a date
-You are prepared to squint at the menu bc it is very dark (but oh-so-cute)
-You are ready to enjoy some great wines at very decent prices.

This is a lovely, cozy, charming wine bar and I am definitely a fan. How ironic that it's right across the street from Le Colonial - I'd choose a night at The Hidden Vine over Le Colonial any day.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
A charming wine lounge, truly hidden in a little alley off of Post Street. Not  a fancy or impressive environment,  but cozy and cute nonetheless. 

Grab a small table or a nice comfy velvet loveseat. 

The service is very friendly and unpretentious and they clearly know their wines.

I would recommend getting the flights, which are organized by region.  On my most recent visit I had 2 flights from  France- one white and one red. Each flight had 3 glasses.  Cost was $10 for the white flight and $18 for the red flight. Both completely worth it! Their pours are very generous and each glass was  excellent. In my experience at wine bars usually a couple of the wines in a flight are not too tasty, but at the Hidden Vine it appears that every glass has been thoughtfully picked out because they are all delicious. 

I came here once before for 2 Australian flights, white and red. Total cost for 2 flights of 4 glasses each ( total 8 glasses) was only $20! Again, the wines were ALL delicious!

I like the way they have little tags on the glasses with the name of the wine on each glass- we used them to play a nice game of blind wine tasting..yes admittedly dorky but fun nonetheless!
author: amy k.

description: Nice wine bar with great service. It's quiet enough to talk but still felt lively - I agree with a previous reviewer that it would be an awesome date spot. I didn't have any of the food, but it looked delicious. I was with a group for my friend's birthday and they put us in the front in an area with a large table and a cool wine tapestry. My only complaint is that they propped the front door open and it was quite chilly. Apparently they did it because the rest of the bar was too hot, but I could see people at the tables near the front looking cold. Seems like their climate control could use a little work, but that's a really minor flaw in an otherwise great wine bar!
author: Anna M.

description: Went by the new place a week ago and really enjoyed it.  The place looks great, it's comfortable and is perfect spot to sit back and have a glass or two of vine.  I tried a wine from my home country of Portugal. It was earthy and just wanted i was seeking...come to find out, the owner is from Portugal too.  I'll definitely be back to have another glass of it and try others.
author: Dilly M.

description: Amazing service. Really above expected.  But so-so actual wines and snacks. Not happy about any of the 6 wines we tasted, house made pickles are very sweet and burrata on bread is with "Serrano" = ham w tomatoes and glops of sweet balsamic and almost no burrata FYI.
author: Ara S.

description: Anyone know if they've actually shut down?  Website still says they're open and located at Cosmo Place but their telephone number goes into a generic voicemail.  What happens if I have a groupon for The Hidden Vine?  Was planning to go there tonight but just say the "announcement" on Yelp.  ??
author: Stephanie E.

description:
A Diamond in the rough...
Angela and David are as sweet as Reislings and  vine knowledgable.
It's cozy and comfy  after a LONG days work.
author: Gemma P.

description:
Hidden Vine isn't entirely off the beaten path, but you could easily walk by it over and over again without noticing it. It is very subtly and cutely tucked into the back of a hotel lobby, and the sign, while present, is understated.  

This little wine bar is charming and low key and comfortable, with a diverse selection of wines and helpful bartenders who will do things like trick you into really liking a glass of Merlot, even though you fancy yourself too cool for such proletarian varietals. You can sip your vino at tables or on plush couches and chairs. The noise level is ambient so conversation is easy.

I can highly recommend this place for a first date. 

(And, if your date happens to be really cute and fun, and you want to get him a little liquored up and see what happens, there are some less civilized bars within easy walking distance.)
author: Angie R.

description:
The Hidden Vine is a great wine bar.  Angela and David are very knowledgeable, friendly, and down to earth.  The wine selection is diverse and interesting, if a little light on burgundies.  They also focus on a special wine region each month.  The current one, Greece, has some excellent fruity, light white wines, perfect for summer sipping.  And the cheese selection is excellent.  

It's a great place, tucked out of the way but accessible.  I felt like I was visiting a friend's living room (my own is not even close to being that cozy).  You can carry on a conversation, try some new wines, and kick back.  

Definitely a hang out for pre- or post-dinner gatherings with good friends.
author: Anh Thu V.

description:
What a little gem of a place!
A friend and I had a delicious dinner at Ryoko's and then popped over to the Hidden Vine for a night cap or rather so I could tie one on.
The wine was delish, the place so cozy, the people unpretentious and down to earth. 

We will meet again hidden Vine, we will meet again.
author: Shawn P.

description:
UPDATE:  

Even better a couple of years down the road.  Angela, David, Eric, Craig and Mary - all a delight.....wonderful selection of wines, not to mention delicious cheese, salami and chutney plates!  

Excellent little wine bar.  Angela and David, the owners, are very knowledgeable and are the perfect hosts.  A great addition to the neighborhood and the ideal place to hook up with friends for a little relaxation and a bite to eat - wonderful cheese and sausage plates.
author: Alison M.

description:
Went here a second time, and it just didn't have the same charm as the first. Plus, the wines were gross.

I ordered a flight of reds, and two of them were just bad. Flabby, uninteresting and served way too cold. The place itself was too cold. The service slow. We jetted out of there in record time.

Not sure why this experience was less thrilling. Can't put my finger on it. But it was such a turn off that I don't even think I'll give it a third chance to break the tie.
author: Brittney G.

description:
Sans stainless steel, funky fixtures and self-conscious self-image, The Hidden Vine manages to effortlessly be the hippest wine bar in town. Tucked away in a dark alley off the beaten track of Union Square, it exudes an old speakeasy charm that only gets better once you navigate the staircase and decend to the basement.

Warm, cozy, intimate with every surface covered in patterned, paisley'd and painted texture. Attentive service, knowledgable hosts, moody lighting, offbeat wines and prices that reflect the retro setting. It doesn't get much better than this without trying too hard.

I just hope it remains somewhat hidden, despite the yelps!
author: shellstar p.

description:
I really like this place. A tiny hole in the wall, it looks like someone's basement turned into a family room. Great place to park yoruself on a couch and enjoy fine wine, and good conversation. They have these wine flights, where you taste 3 wines for $15 or something ... and they are much larger than the 'tastes' you get at wineries in Napa Valley ... I was pretty buzzed after that. Then they have their cheese plates, and their cheese special of the day. When I went last, they had a truffled burratta ... that's like two of my favorite things in the world put into one -- how can you go wrong with that? 
I've only been twice (within the same week!) and look forward to going back. FYI, they change their tasting menus every month ... I should make a goal to go there once a month!
author: Antara B.

description: Love this place.  It's low key, but the price is right.  I love the monthly highlights on a region, and this year, I have tastings from Spain, Washington State, etc.  Limited food selection, but good choices for cheese and a tasty chorizo.  The one downside is that the place is small and fills up quick.
author: Peter L.

description:
What a great hidden place!  The entrance is in the alley kitty korner to Le Colonial so it's definitely off of the beaten track.  Thank you yelpers, as this was solely your doing!  

I met up with Arnie, Jonny, and Angela this past Wednesday for happy hour and we thought to look to Yelp for a change of pace. The glowing reviews were true to form and we were all pleasantly inebriated by the end of it.  Arnie ordered a single glass off of the menu, but the rest of us went for some of the taste comparisons.  I love that the labels are turned down so that you can guess and compare what you're tasting.

We also tried some beautiful cheeses!  An herb goat cheese and a super buttery cow girl creamery cow's cheese.  Served with our order of salami, olives, bread, and chutney!  All was very good. 

The atmosphere was indeed intimate, mellow, and unpretentious!  The decor reminds me of grandma's living room, but it was nice.  It was very quiet when we arrived, but we didn't notice so much after the wine was poured...hope we weren't too loud.
author: Nicole N.

description:
Cozy little wine bar that has reasonable prices ($7 for a glass, $12 for a cheese plate with 2 types of cheese and chutney, french bread). Attached to the St. Andrew's hotel, but still hidden enough.

My mom claimed her Chardonnay was the best she's had in a long time...and it was only $6 a glass and $22 for the bottle. From Chile, the feature of the month.

Thought it was cool they offer a 30% uncorked discount on wines you purchase from the bar and take home.
author: Kelly R.

description: Great wine bar, went early before dinner one night so I can't say what it's like later at night, but in the early evening it was great, good wine choices and service, nice and different arrangements for seating, fireplace, couches, bocce ball outside, really liked the atmosphere and hope to go back.
author: Ellen S.

description:
I've been to this place twice.  Once we got there super early before the crowd came to attack the cheese spread (and they do attack!).

The selection is pretty good.  The staff is very nice and helpful.  No wine snobs here!

Oh, the second time I came it was so packed that we couldn't even get to the bar.  It was about 9pm on a Saturday night, so I'm definitely not surprised.
author: Chris M.

description:
Having been to the other local "speakeasy" type place earlier in the evening, Hidden Vine really felt more like a hidden speakeasy to me than the former place. Dark alley, barely marked location, down the stairs. . . . into someones living room. Seriously, I could have sworn this spot use to be someones home with the couches, the fireplace, the kitchen and the bar area. I was wrong (we asked) but were told that was the feel they went for. 

The staff were super nice and helpful and really seemed to enjoy their job  (what a concept). I tried the Piedmont Red flight and we had the cheese plate. Yum. I stayed away from the truffles, but my friend tried them and ate them ALL! I believe that means they were also very good. 

I can't find a single thing to complain about!
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
Hidden Vine is lovely, good, nice.  You know all those pretty lovely things that wine bars are -- but it still makes me sleepy.

The owners LOVE wine.  They will talk about your selections with you, make suggestions, and are generally really sweet and caring -- about wine.  

The cheese plates are always carefully put together, pairing really delicious fruit chutneys and amazing cheeses.  If you've never heard of the Cowgirl Creamery,  well then run out and make their acquaintance.  

Mt. Tam cheese, I love you.

Sorry -- tangent.  

Back to the Hidden Vine.  Great place if you like wine, cheese and quiet.  Not the best Saturday Martini, Canape, Martini, falling asleep dizzy with one foot on the floor stop, but a good Thursday Pinot Grigio, Gouda, Baguette, go home and cuddle stop.

If you know what I mean... 

and I think you do.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I think the only thing left to complete the ambiance for this place would be to have a corner where you could smoke, with the wisps barely filling out the room.  But, then you'd have that nasty smell.  That the main entrance is in an alleyway and down some stairs makes it even that much cooler.

They have a wide selection - not incredibly deep, but a good smattering from around the world.  And, they have some excellent flights to match your mood, one month, a comparison of one grape from different regions, or a European red flight the next.  And I wouldn't be surprised if they wouldn't come up with one if you asked.

The staff is extremely eager to help out - either to make sure your party is seated comfortably, to helping you choose your wine.  Whether you're a complete novice, or an oenophile, they'll speak on your level.
author: masa s.

description:
Like a subterranean safe house for wine lovers. Once you secure a seat, your work is done. 

Located across Cosmo lane from Le Colonial, it can be a tough place to find. I haven't memorized a route to the place on purpose. It is, after all, called the *hidden* vine, and it isn't exaclty the worst neighborhood to find yourself lost in. 

The Hidden Vine stocks all of your California favorites, and in addition features a different region around the world every month. This gives you two flights to start with. They also have a selection of wine books and a very knowledgeable staff. So, if you want to talk tannins, you'll be in good company here....
author: Raoul D.

description: The early 20's crowd running giggling and screaming in and out of the Hidden Vine set the mood for an incredibly unromantic, over-priced, unappetizing evening. The $12 "cheese" plate, with four slices of cheese, is not worth the price, the chunks of stale bread left something to be desired, the "green olives" that tasted strangely like black olives from a can, the strange fruit paste, the music fed through an ipod near a phone that kept getting phone calls and would get distortion buzz... all of it, terrible.  The only saving grace about this place was the kind bartender and waitress, sorry to say that she was on her own and probably could stand to use some help in this place. Immediately after headed over to the trusty Hotel Biron, where parking is readily available and the cheese is far more palatable, the fruit is fresh, and the bread is soft and edible.
author: E. P.

description: After having dinner down the street, I wanted to find someplace to have a glass of red wine for dessert. Searching through my Yelp app I stumbled upon The Hidden Vine, and boy am I glad I did. I took a seat at the bar with Carolyn, who was extremely knowledgable about the wines she was pouring, and let me try more than a few wines before I finally found something I liked. I ended up doing the Old World Pinot Noir side by side tasting for $15, and let me tell you the pours were amazing! Drunk Tash for sure. They also have an AMAZING cheese plate that was served with McQuade's Celtic Chutney. I got two plates. It was that good. The two flavors of Chutney were Fig and Ginger and Apple and Red Chili, highly recommended! I love this place and will def go back next time I am in the neighborhood!
author: Natasha C.

description:
The Hidden Vine is a fabulous, personality-infused local relax-after-a-good-meal kind of bar with an unpretentious yet charming atmosphere conducive to great conversation with the company you bring.

Once again, we picked the place thanks to Yelp (I feel like I'm "giving back to the community" every time I write a review because they are so helpful).    True to its name, the place is a bit hidden from the main road, but we did enter from the outside entrance and down the stairs.  Service had the hospitality of a multi-generational family establishment - warm, friendly, extremely knowledgeable (I believe she quoted the maker of our wine to be one of the few who did not graduate from UC Davis; I was impressed they keep records of even the educational background of winemakers yet are so unpretentious and fun to talk to).  

The wine menu is non-connoisseur-friendly for those like myself - each section has the bolded "type" of red or white ("Earthy", "Fruity", "Bold Tasting" I can recall were some, with further descriptions per section).  Prices were extremely reasonable, and on Fridays (which is the day we went) they have 20% off bottles.  We ordered a bottle of a "fruity red," a 2003 Niner (I believe a Zinfandel blend) and the hard sheep's and soft goat cheese.  The cheese plates come with dried blueberries, apricots and the seasoned spread, and the thinly sliced bite-sized bread.  I nibbled for hours and ordered more of the hard sheep's milk, which was sparsely studded with peppercorn.   Two cheeses for $12, and each additional was $6, and portions were very decent.

To me, The Hidden Vine deserves five stars because it is truly charming and memorable.  I feel that with drinking establishments, it's not so much the wine or the food but the fusion of that and more that will give the place a certain necessary "aura" to earn five stars.  This aura at The Hidden Vine cannot be duplicated - charmingly arranged tables and chairs with different shapes and sizes, carefully placed candles, dimly lit atmosphere and very knowledgeable and friendly staff make this hidden gem five-star-worthy.
author: Theresa K.

description:
Owner operated says it all. Everyone here is so passionate about the wine they pour, the cheese and salami they serve and even the orangiata soda to "freshen the palate". I would say that the decor and furnishings are pretty drab but I think this is what I love most about the place. It's hidden, it is casual, and the bum's outside in the Tenderloin make you even more happy to be inside with some wine by Sean Thackery. 

Cheeses are local and often by cowgirl creamery. A small selection of salami usually a slight bit thick to add some depth to your bite. A compote of tomato or fruit chutney is always along side as well as a few pieces of dried fruit. XoXo chocolates are also on hand for when you battle the big Napa Cabernet's.

Wine flights usually don't impress me but they are always of good themes. There is an option of just two wines and do a blind compare and contrast. 

I recommend going late, from 5-8 they are usually more busy with a pre-dinner crowd but later it it perfect for being a real wine nerd.
author: Lauren B.

description: Great little place. Use the yelp check in offer! Also try the wine samplers on the back of the menu. Fun to try different different wines with friends. Reasonable priced and helpful and knowledgable staff.
author: Sarah F.

description:
This is such a cozy, warm, and uplifting little wine bar.  If it's not too busy,  there are a few overstuffed chairs that you can sink into while enjoying your wine and hors d'oeuvres.  I definitely recommend this place, and it's the perfect romantic spot to relax after a nice date.

Plus, the 2006 Poppy Pinot Noir is fantastic!

Bonus: High grade chocolate sampler.  The chocolate at this wine bar is so rich and decadent that it puts See's Candies to shame!!!
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
The best wine bar in San Francisco I have been to.

Wine -The place has very solid wine selections from all regions, including many wine flights. I am just a fan of wine, not a wine geek.  Therefore I can't say if their menu is better than the other place. But the people here are very nice to help us to find some good wines, never been snobby. They are friendly and very knowledgeble with thier wines. 

Atmosphere - I've been looking for the good place for quiet and close conversation. This bar is not noisy even for the weekends...it is very exceptional as to be close to Union Square. 

The decor is classic and cozy, even romantic with candles and fireplace.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Sadly Dave and Angela are no more, they sold the place. . . they will be missed.  X^(  

The new folks appeared anxious to help friends and I,  however we were there more or less to see Angela/Dave; we thanked them and went on our way.  

I cannot commit on the new owner's selection of wines, but can commit on the friendly service.
author: Cris B.

description:
This is a perfect "end of the night" place to go on a date after you have been to a show and have had dinner and want to have some place cozy to get to know each other a little better.  
It feels like someones living room with the fireplace and small cottage effect.   I tried a flight of port with some cheese and truffles that were delicious.   It would have been easy to spend 3 hours here in the warm atmosphere enjoying nice wine and the ambiance.  This will definitely be a place I frequent after an evening out in SF.
author: Kristine K.

description:
The Wine bar is indeed Hidden inside the Hotel Fitzgerald on Jones Street. The cozy intimate feeling make the place perfect for a date or meeting with friends where you can actual talk and have a conversation with out the noise and and music and need to ask "what you just say - sorry I can not hear you?". every seems to enjoy the place and having great time, The furniture and the decor are rustic, old with big counter and large comfy chairs around it. Sara, the sommelier was great! fun and patient was us crazy girls. She know about wine the same as I know about shoes.

We will be back!
author: Jackie K.

description:
A very warm, cozy, romantic, intimate wine lounge to have meaningful (or even not so meaningful) conservations with friends or your partner in crime. (Nice place for a date!) The wine selection is great, the cheese selection great, olives marinated yummy, and they even offer Navarro grape juice if you have a non-alcoholic drinker in the mix. It gets busy sometimes after work hours (especially Fridays) and a little warm...that never stopped us from just enjoying the moment there. 

The staff there know the wines and if you want to know more, all you have to do is ask - they are really friendly and not intrusive.
author: Dharti A.

description:
Tucked behind a hotel lobby with a parking lot acess through an alley, the hidden vine is truely hidden! 

But what a find! I really like the warm and relax atmosphere in the bar. The setup is a lttle old fashion but not stuffy. The wine selection is good and there was a different region highlighted each month(Germany in October). I really enjoy the various flight option.  There is a tasting of different resiling, comparing German resiling with California resiling, comparing various German white and red. 

Finally a feature that all wine bar should have! Wine tag to tell you which glass contains which wine. If tasting with friends, it is easy to get the glasses mixed up.
author: hsiao c.

description:
After walking past this discreet hole-in-the wall everyday for over a year; I finally took the bf here to enjoy a relaxing late afternoon snack  after an agressive afternoon of elbowing fellow shoppers down on Union Square.

For starts, most read-able wine menu I've ever seen.  Starting with whites, the menu is broken down into a spectrum of the lightest whites to the boldest reds.  Perfect for those who are not too sure about regions etc.. but know how they like their wines to taste.

Second kudos goes to the gentleman serving up the libations- recommended a fabulous cheese to pair with our spicy reds- a nice, creamy burrata with truffle oil and sea salt... yumm.

Best part of the experience was the dark atmosphere with plush, tucked away nooks and krannies for you to sip, eat, and relax with your favorite person.
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
I went last weekend and really needed my experience to soak in so I could write the proper review. I didn't have the pleasure of visiting under the old owners, but the new owners seem to have done just fine. My friend and I were on a wine mission last Saturday, we wanted something low key where we could hang out, talk sex, guys, relationships, not be bothered, have good reasonable priced drinks, and just enjoy ourselves. 

The Hidden Vine was an excellent choice! We sat at the bar where Chad talked to us about the flights, and his favorites as well as other customer favorites. I chose the flight of whites and my friend got the flight of reds. I am normally not a Riesling type so I tend not to order them, but Chad insisted that I wouldn't regret it and boy was he right. I LOVED it. After my flight I ordered a glass of it. My friend had nothing but great things to say about the reds, and even took home the little paper rings they put on the glasses to tell you what you're drinking. 

I love how you feel like you are hanging out in a good friends living room. The couches are cozy, the lighting is cozy, the music is light and nice. I saw a lot of couple and double dates, a few girls hanging out with friends. It got crowded around 10:30 p.m. so I was glad we got there and snagged 2 of the 3 bar seats. Jared (the other bartender) is cute and stuck up for my love of ACDC, Led Zep, and Black Sabbath - I am sure Camille and I's conversation was completely telling at some point, but he didn't let on that he was thinking what sluts we were in college! 2 points! 

I will be back with my other 2 best friends when I get them to come visit me! I hope Chad and Jared are ready!
author: Jessica R.

description: I love this place! Great selection of wine, beautiful ambience and superb service. Total awesomeness.
author: Nurya A.

description:
I don't think I could say anything that hasn't already been said about this place. But...

I honestly could come here once a week. It's perfect - you go and sit, get some cheese, get a flight of wines, and chill for the night. The owners are SUPER. None of this "I know about wine and you don't so I'm better than you" junk that you can get sometimes. They are totally into what they are doing, and are enthused about sharing. PERFECT.
author: Kristen O.

description:
Had to check out the top-rated wine bar on yelp as part of my monthly wine tasting event.

My group was disappointed by the by-the-glass wine choices.

The ambiance and the location were awesome, but this is more of a share a good bottle of wine rather than the trend of getting top wines by the glass.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I took my friend to Hidden Vine for the first time. The conversation went something like this:

"Dude, why are you taking me to this place? It looks like someone's basement rec room or something..."

Yeah, don't let the look of this place fool you. It's rec room chic. I really like it, actually -- it feels homey and comfortable without trying too hard. 

A wise man once told me that wine was meant to be enjoyed by the bottle, not by the glass. With the affordable prices, good selection, and friendly service, it's hard not to share a bottle with a good friend. Props to any place whose maximum capacity is around 30 people. This place is great -- lots of character and great wine.

I give it the rare and coveted 5 star rating!
author: Charles H.

description: Google maps still lists it as permanently closed and was pleased to find out they were closed for the holidays and have adjusted my rating accordingly.    This place is great and highly recommend it.
author: John C.

description:
I love this place!  Not only do they have a great wine list and do fun monthly flights, but they have the best red chairs.  If you are in the mood and can get there early enough to snag one (or four) of them, you will be in heaven.

And 20% off bottles on Fridays. ..now that is a good start to a Friday.
author: Valerie H.

description:
I'm rather excited to be the 300th reviewer of the Hidden Vine.

I do not go here nearly as often as I would like to. I like going to bars you need to walk downstairs to get to. It adds to the ambiance of entering something hidden and secretive.

They have a great selection of wines at very reasonable prices. You can enjoy your wine at a bar seat or at one of there comfortable tables, which are very nice.

If you get hungry, they do have a nice cheese selection to try. Also, there are many restaurants in the area you can go to if you are seeking something more filling. 

This place is great to go with people from out of town or to go on a date with a love interest or a friend you want to impress. Not loud, very relaxing and comfortable.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Oh wow, so many people know about this place - it's amazing that my friends & I still manage to get seats everytime we go.  Well, I'll add my voice to the chorus: it's fabulous.  Great wine, friendly staff, and free cheese, olives and little nibbly things on Thursdays.   A great place to hang out.

Update 1/5/07 - Still love this place, despite the crowds.  Mmm, cheese plates.  The owners are as nice as can be.

Update 11/07 - On a date with someone you like?  Try to sit in the nook.  ;)
author: DD B.

description:
If ever there were a cool dive wine bar---this is it!!
The owners are knowledgeable and super friendly and don't make you feel like an ass fore not knowing your shit when it comes to wine...
A cozy, dark little lounge with an old school feel to it....very good for dates....
I'll toast to that:)
author: erica c.

description:
I loved this place! It is definitely hidden in the lobby of a random hotel, but once you find it, you don't want to leave... I kept myself from giving them 5 stars because the decor is not really my style, but all the rest was perfect. The service was prompt, knowledgeblae with no attitude, the wines were great, and the cheese was plenty! 
The nicest touch was that they bring out the flights with little labels at the bottom of each glass so that you won't have to try to remember each. You know how hard that gets after a few sips! Also, for the "comparison" flight, they bring the labels upside down, so you can try to guess. Of course I was totally wrong :(

All in all, the perfect place to start the night or wind down after a nice dinner.
author: Ayse B.

description:
Went here for a private party, nearly a year ago. It was great. Had a good time with some friends and wine!!

Update and star added: 

The evening crowd on a Friday is crazy BUSY. The waitress said the wait could be between 15 minutes to an hour! Luckily we got a great cozy spot. The cheese was amazing and the wines we got were tasty. The winetender was SOO helpful, my friends and I really appreciated all of her suggestions. Oh! and 20% off bottles (We had gone on a Friday evening from 7 pm - 9 pm)
author: Anita C.

description:
stephy s. is dead-on about this place.  I'm sincerely bummed that I don't live in San Francisco because LA is just a bit too far to frequent the Hidden Vine!!

This place is a true gem.  The small size, cozy atmosphere, friendly and accommodating staff,  and being so close to my friend's apartment! 

Great place to have a nice conversation with someone you trust (or don't trust but enjoy the company for some reason).  Do not forget to order a plate of chocolate truffles.  I'm still dreaming about them back in LA....
author: Yoko M.

description:
This is basically a converted vacant space in a hotel converted into a non-pretentious wine bar.  Great selection of wines that can cater to large preferences.  Servers are very nice.  Only 3 stars because honestly nothing amazing but also nothing horrible.  Great place to have a relaxing night with some wine.  

I personally prefer Bin 38 but i think the crowd might be too much to handle sometimes.
author: Charles C.

description:
Nice cozy place 
to slow down 

relax and enjoy 

Chateuneuf-du-Pape
Cow Girl creamery Mt Tam
XOX Truffles
author: AZAM A.

description:
What a gem! The Hidden Vine is that special place that you hope nobody discovers so you can have it all to yourself, but unfortunately it never works out that way. 

The staff is incredibly helpful and knowledgeable, the wines are well priced and diverse (I especially love the changing flights), the atmosphere is cozy and adorable, and free cheese night on Thursdays is unbeatable!
author: Ava S.

description:
I can't believe 227 people have reviewed this place!  It's physically hidden, but I guess it's not that hidden from all the yelpers.

I would have never found this place w/o yelp.  20% off bottles at happy hour last friday.  I don't know though, the scene is totally not my cup of tea.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
I totally love this place! The service is excellent (especially when the owners are there). Bottom line is great wine and a cozy atmosphere!

5-1-08 UPDATE
Went for a glass of wine last night the place just felt different. It was the first time I've ever gone when none of the owners were there. I asked the server and sure enough, Angela and Dave sold the place. I could cry. Angela and Dave were the bomb! The totally made that place and without them there it's just not the same. 
The menu is still the same which is great, but there's no more bottle night on Fridays... Bummer.
author: J J.

description: NOT good for a group-- I went with co-workers on 6/12 and it was a mess, just poor service all around. When my self and another co-worker got there there were no other guests there and nobody came by to take our order, I ended up going to the bar to get a bottle menu and then again to order. Then two more in our party came and nobody came by to give them glasses so again, I went to the bar to ask (and confirm we did indeed have a server) then another two members of our party joined us and we needed another bottle of wine and finally a server came, then they were out of the Sea Smoke we had wanted (i get that being out of wine isn't the servers fault but still, its a wine bar, their menu should be up to date), then they were super slow to bring the next bottle and then we had to track down the waitress to get our check-- literally I got up and had to walk around to find her. To add insult to the whole experience they built in a charge of 20% because we had a party of 6, now generally I would have no problem with this except I should have gotten the 20% since i ended up going to the bar 1) to get the bottle list 2) to order a bottle of wine 3) to get more glasses and 4) to find the check--in the course of about 45 minutes. When I pointed this out she asked what I wanted and I told her that I thought she should do what she thought was right. She left the 20% on and lost a customer. Good luck with all that. Two stars for good location and ambiance.
author: Kristina K.

description:
I feel like i'm giving up professional trade secrets on this one.   The Hidden Vine is awesome!   Excellent selection of wines and all reasonably priced.

AND there is magic about the atmosphere here.  First, it isn't noisy at all so you can talk to your guests without having to scream, and its private enough that others aren't going to listen in on your conversations..

The living room type furniture is perfect and so comfortable you won't want to leave.  The lighting is romantic and very inviting to get close.  Need i say more?  It doesn't get much better than this!
author: Greg G.

description:
I like to play games when I am drinking with friends.  It's not just me... how do you think Beer Pong became so popular?  Why do you think the basketball game at Mauna Loa always has a line?  The crowd around the pool tables at Savoy and Fly Bar?  The dart board at Black Horse Deli?  Drinking and games go so well together.  Sometimes, though, you need to feel more like an adult. (huh? what's that?!)

Well, The Hidden Vine has turned drinking games upscale.  Those nights you don't feel like shaking your tailfeathers across the alley at Le Colonial, cross the street and go down the itty bitty steep staircase.  In the tiny basement of the Fitzgerald Hotel sits the friendliest litte wine bar that ever was.  The menu changes to focus on different regions, and thus offers various flights from that region.  Our party of 5 sampled a flight of whites from Loire, France, and noshed on some tasty cheese, baguette, and fig ginger compote (!) before the games began...

By games, I mean the grownup kind.  The Hidden Vine offers comparisons of wines and champagnes.  My boyfriend and I guessed the French vs. California Brut Rose correctly.  This is the only time I would have been okay losing because that would have meant another try ("can we order another pleeeeease?")

The staff was super friendly, not at all snobby like I feared at a wine bar.  Besides the extremely high temperature (but that's unavoildable in a tiny space filled with people), I couldn't have picked a better spot for great wine and conversation.  I wouldn't bring a large party (more than 4 or so), as it's hard to sit together.  The few tables they have are very small.

I'd read about the place on Yelp, so I'm happy to say it came through and I'll be frequenting this place for sure!
author: Marina Maven C.

description:
I almost hesitate to write a good review of this place, fearing that this tiny little candlelit wine bar will no longer become 'hidden." Very cute & romantic, with cozy velvet chairs and plenty of ambience. Not as much wine available by the glass as you would expect, but enough choices to satisfy all tastes. Best seat is a little alcove fit for two. 

Perfect place to cozy up to and have intimate conversation with friends or a loved one, especially after having dinner at Ryoko next door.
author: Sabine S.

description: Turns out, Hidden Vine is truly hidden. The force of five iPhones still could not seem to help us track this hotel bar down. Since we walked like twenty-odd blocks in circles to find it (and hey, I'm from NC where we have to DRIVE everywhere -- this gal ain't used to pounding the pavement in heels!), I was pretty excited when we got there and could just sit down already. It's teeny, so kind of on the cramped side -- but it has this self-elevating atmosphere that conjured up The Algonquin hotel in Manhattan and seems like it should include activities like pipe smoking, martini lunches, and stuffy talk about great literature. Unfortunately, what it DID include was a stuffy bartender. Service issues aside though, loved the bubbly flight I got --nice solid pours--and the fact that they put a little tag on the glasses so you can keep everything straight.
author: Christina G.

description:
All about the ambience, less so about the wine.  Loved the cheese selection, but the wines themselvers were disappointing.  First of all, when I go to a wine bar, I want to be able to order a "taste" not a glass, not a bottle.  Too many of the wines were bottles only.

I'm serious about tasting, so this place is great for hanging out, not much for the serious wine afficionado.  

~Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description: This place is such a gem - tucked away across the street from Le Colonial, I don't think many people notice it.  The space is really comfortable with lots of couches and open areas.  The wine list is extensive, and the service is really prompt and nice.  When I was there, it was a little quiet, especially for me and my rowdy friends.  :-)  It's a really nice place to chill out with some friends over a few glasses of wine...
author: Wendy L.

description: Love this little place. Hidden and comfy. Staff is attentive, great wine list, warm decor.
author: Michelle G.

description: Labelled as a hotel, this indescript wine bar is quiet, sophisticated, and elegant in one of San Francisco's more eclectic neighbourhoods. Mostly tourists and guests from the Fitzgerald, I did like the fact that Sarah, the innkeeper, was able to narrow down to my favourite wine at the end. Given that I had almost 8 different ones, I left her with a promise that I intend to go back and actually pay for my wine. And I will keep said promise.
author: Hasan D.

description:
OMG!! What a perfect experience after such a :( experience at Le Colonial. 

So this place is approx 12 steps from the door of Le Colonial (across random alleyway). I used iPhone Yelp to find it, and what. a. gem, even though it is in the basement of some random hotel. We walked down a few stairs to find an extremely comfortable, inviting atmosphere. We grabbed a table (bummed that cute little cove wasn't open) and perused the wine list. The bf had this grand idea of getting truffles as dessert and he couldn't have had a better idea in the world - what indulgent little thingamajigs on a plate that go perfectly with red wine. 

This place is perfect for everyone (except, likely, those heading above the Le Colonial). Groups looking to meet up. Couples. Old friends. New friends. Solo. We moved from a table to the couch across the bar (big mistake - I was so tired and the couch is sleep-inducing). 

I wish The Hidden Vine was in the basement of MY building.
author: Purvi R.

description:
Be prepared to have everyone stare at you when you walk in. The stairs are like a stage that hovers above the audience. So don't fall. Or do. It'll be funny for the rest of us. 

We paraded in there one Valentine's Day last year, and it was jammed, so we left. But I have wanted to go back since. I finally did recently, and was glad I remembered. The service was great. One guy, but he was very attentive to all his tables. He even chased down some dine-and-dashers (and then the girl forgot her wallet on her seat. Nice.). 

We each had a comparison (he poured 2 very healthy "half" glasses of 2 wines to compare), and then I ordered a flight (again, very generous pours). Not the best wines, at least for my taste, but very good. There are so many wines, and they're always changing the tasting menu, so you're bound to find something you like each time. Walked out feeling VERY good for a reasonable price. Quiet, dark, lots of 2 top tables, so perfect for a date (if you have something to talk about, otherwise, kinda awkward). 

No vegan food on the menu other than olives and bread. So swing by Millennium first for a bite - just a couple blocks away.
author: Kalista B.

description:
This place is tucked away in the back of a hotel - or accessible via an alley - I'd prefer to enter through the hotel...I came here with the girlfriends and had a wonderful time once we finally found a place to sit down!

Pros: Wide selection, cozy atmosphere, personable owner, tasty food to pair with your wine...

Cons: Fairly tiny - can be hard to find seats, a little bit pricy...

Helpful Tip  - I noticed that the owner tries to proactively manage who gets the next table (vs. a first come first serve policy) when people are waiting - so check in with her if you are coming with a group and trying to get a seat...

All in all - I had a positive time while I was here and recall that the owner brought us a little extra cheese when she was out of one of the other food items we asked for - I thought that was a very fair way to handle the situation!
author: Kimberly K.

description: Super cute wine bar that reminds me more of a cozy living room than the next trendy place. Comfortable and nonpretentious.  The best part is you don't have to yell to catch up with your friends.  Serves appetizers too.
author: La A.

description:
If my two of my favorite places in Phoenix (Roosevelt Tavern and Lost Leaf) came together and had a genius lovechild, this would be it. 

I love everything about this spot. Whenever I think back on my first trip to 'Frisco, my mind recalls the hour or so spent here. In some dark room in a basement which could only be found down an alley of some indistinct street. 

A great spot to slow down and have some good drinks and intimate conversation. I'm a fan and will definitely be back.
author: Dia M.

description:
My favorite place to just chill and hang out with friends at night, any night of the week!  (except when they're closed ;)

It's cozy, friendly, and just a cool place that makes you feel all warm and fuzzy inside (with a little help from wines ;) kind of a place.
It could get pretty darn crowded on the weekends, but it's totally worth it.  I do prefer to go during the week though when it's nice and mellow.

I also love the cheeses they have here, and for those of you who do not drink, you don't have to feel left out here, they serve some delicious grape juices in wine glasses.
author: Sophia F.

description: This place is an awesome mellow wine lounge. It is kinda scary going to this place because it is in the TL, but if you like wine, check this place out. I was impressed by how simple yet nice this place is. The employee's are nice and patient. They waited forever for me to decide on a glass of wine and gave me a few suggestions. Minus one star for location.
author: Alex G.

description:
I still love this place.  We returned this past trip to SF and had a great time.  It was a little less crowded which was nice and we made friends with our bartenders and a local who shared a plate of truffles and desert wines with us (Thanks Paula!).  I discovered that I do NOT like port, no matter what sort of chocolate you are serving it with!  

Thanks to the bartenders who were truthful that the Malbec on the list was no good, but the Tempranillo was excellent.
author: Lauren L.

description: We held the after-party for our wedding at the Hidden Vine.  It was perfect.  A wonderfully casual but classy atmosphere, they set up the front room with food for our guests and also held the Bocce court for us.  Our guests left feeling like they'd been invited to an extra-exclusive part of the wedding, and the out-of-towners left with a memory of San Francisco at its best.  The staff was great too -- they took care of everything, and did it all in under a week's notice.  I was impressed.  Recommended.
author: Kurt P.

description:
This is a really cute place, but it's tiny and can get really hot when it fills up and the fireplace candles are raging. It's a nice enough place to dress up if you want and laid back enough for jeans and a t-shirt if you don't

They have a good selection of wines and the staff is patient and helpful. The wine flights are a good bargain and you get to try a variety wines from different locations and wineries. It is a little pricey though and might be cheaper to split a bottle of wine for the table rather than buying by the glass.

A good place to take out of town guests for a casual evening out or drinks before a show.
author: ms. jared g.

description:
I was looking for some place special to take my girlfriend for her bithday and Yelp came through! With a little help from the GPS we found parking a block away and entered through the hotel lobby. (I'd read on Yelp that the entrance through the alley in the back  might be a little scary for ladies at night.) The second we walked through the door I knew we'd found a gem. It was 9:30 on a Saturday night and the place is so small i thought we'd never sit down. We we did find a nook at the end of the tiny bar. She sat in the empty stool and I stood. By the time our very attentive server had given us the rundown on the wine list and cheese selection a table opened up under a cool jazz painting.
