The lighting, the mood and the sounds were unlike anything I've experienced in this city. It was almost like we were not in San Francisco, yet you could only find a place like this in San Francisco.

We had a bottle of 2006 St. Claire Pinot Noir from New Zealand and it was perfectly paired with the suggested Cowgirl creamy,Oregon blue cheese and mango chutney. Delicious stuff!

It was just about $50 including tip and I felt like it was a bargain. It was a big, big hit. We promised that day to take her parents there on their anniversary and we did. The rave reviews continued. 

I was just going to give it 4 stars because its so small, but it's part of the charm and you always seen to find a place to fit anyway. We can't wait to go back and maybe this time mingle with some of the other smiling Yelpers instead of pretending like we are the only ones who know about this place. After all we owe it all to you, thanks  

See you there!
author: Anthony A.

description:
Cozy room that makes a nice first stop before dinner -- can't really imagine it wall-to-wall people, it could get claustrophobic really quick. (it was already getting a little table-sharky at 7:30 on a Wednesday).  Solid wine list , and if I lived in the area I could imagine making this a semi-regular drop-in.  

Why only 3 stars?  The service was inexplicably slow (though friendly).  There were two waiters covering the floor for maybe 12 customers, and it took a good 10 minutes for a glass of champagne to make it from the bar area to my table 8 feet away.  Don't make me wait for my first post-work drink!
author: Nancy P.

description: As a long-time fan of Hidden Vine, I was sadly disappointed to see how much the place had gone downhill on a recent visit. Now I know how people who grew up in Detroit in the 40s and 50s must feel when they go home. Maybe I just caught the place on a bad night, but all of the cozy charm and knowledge of wine that former owners Dave & Angela brought to the table was missing. There are just too many other good wine bars in SF to put up with mediocrity... NEXT!
author: Chris B.

description:
I would like to personally thank every yelper on here for helping me find such an amazing place my first time to San Fran. I had business in Walnut Creek, CA this past Friday (2/23/07), and it just so happens that I have a few friends that live in the Bay Area, so I was able to spend my first weekend in San Fran. I have been getting into wine lately, and wanted to come up with a place that even my guests hadn't been to. Of course when searching for wine bars, The Hidden Vine came up.

This place is absolutely awesome. The laid back staff are in t-shirts (the girl working there that night happened to be in a brown Yelp t-shirt), and everyone there is extremely helpful and knowledgeable about wine. We ended up wanting to do reds that night, and they suggested two bottles that were absolutely amazing. In fact, the first one we had I actually wrote down. It was the Chateau de Segries, Rhone Valley, France. I definitely gotta find it again back home on the east coast.

If you have a largish party, try and get in this place a bit early. Perhaps before 10:00pm. I was with a group of four, and we were there for 15 min or so before a group got up and we literally pounced on the tiny table.

Overall, I definitely expect to be back in San Fran in the next few months, and while I will constantly be trying new things, I intend on visiting my new favorite wine bar.
author: Timothy A.

description:
I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could but I'm nice so I'll round up. 

Very low-key and intimate setting. Great for a small group or 1-on-1 with someone. It's small and the more people yelp about it the harder it will be to get a seat. I enjoyed the wine I had here but I can't say much more about it because I was pretty toasted by the time we rolled in.
author: Chris S.

description:
Just a great place to end the work week or hit up before heading out for dinner at Le Colonial or Pakwan--depending on your budget.  The waitstaff was extremely friendly and knowledgable about the selections.  I did a Syrah flight with emphasis on Washington wines which was quite tasty.  Definitely get their cheese or charcuterie plate.  Loved the dried blueberries!!

I'll be back.  It is small so be prepared to stand in a corner, by a wall or under the stairs on certain nights. :)
author: Paul D.

description:
What happens at the Hidden Vine....stays on your pallet.  oh well..you get the idea.  A slice of heaven that would make even the most awkward guy impress his date.  Romantic, cute, velvet-ey, with a nice apricot finish....

92 pts!
author: Vince C.

description:
Nice, interesting, and different wines in a kitchsy atmosphere.  You might think you were stepping into a 50's murder mystery movie.  The owners (a husband and wife) have a nice place for a drink but would liven it up more with a few more cheese and dessert dishes.

A bit of a pickup joint, hangout spot, and hotel bar all wrapped up in a cozy place.
author: Gene D.

description:
Ok, first thing you need to know about the Hidden Vine:
Take the name seriously.
It's nestled within the Hotel Biron, which took me more than a few trips back and forth past the entrance to figure out. But once I was inside, I couldn't bring myself to leave! I came in by myself to kill some time and sample a wine flight before heading to another bar to meet some friends. The atmosphere could be described as similar to, if such a thing exists, a Grandma's Dungeon. The lights are kept low, but comfy couches and chairs in olive green and brown tones abound. Lot's of places to sit with 3 or 4 friends and get cozy 'n tipsy. Not like wine bars in the Marina where you need to sit up straight and behave. This place is relaxed, yet manages to remain classy.
Sarah, my bartender for the evening, was exceedingly knowledgeable as a certified sommelier. She was not, however, overwhelming or condescending in any way with her advice and recommendations. She realizes that not everyone knows the difference between Syrah and Petit Sirah, and keeps that in mind when speaking with her customers. Since the bar was pretty quiet this particular Wednesday night, we got to talking and I told her that I was in the process of studying wine for my job as a server/bartender. Her response was to present me with the most amazing blind taste test / information session I could have ever imagined. I learned more in that one night than in any wine class I've ever taken! I'm going back tonight for more - I just can't stay away!
author: Tanya K.

description: I too was heading to the Hidden Vine tonight and saw that announcement on yelp that they've moved yet there is no new location......seems like a livingsocial scam....hmmmm.   Weird.
author: R H.

description:
A nice, cozy, quiet place to sit back and enjoy a bottle of wine and some conversation. 
We got there right when it opened, so it was very quiet. The gentleman who served us was very laid back. 
We ordered a bottle of Syrah, very reasonable in price. 
They do have a small, limited cheese menu. No cheeses that will blow away a fromager, but they are safe bets. The cheeses are served with half a sliced baguette and some local made chutney. 

I would definitely recommend this place to anybody looking to enjoy some wine in a cozy, dark environment. 
It's a great way to start your night out...
author: Koli H.

description: Cool little wine bar.  I'm not way into wine, but I definitely want  to go back here some time.
author: Michael E.

description: The only reason that I checked out the Hidden Vine was because of the reviews on Yelp and I must say that they were pretty dead on.  The Hidden Vine is seriously a hidden place (I thought I had the address wrong) but it was secretly tucked away and inside it was nice, quaint and relaxing.  Definitely a lunge type feel.  The wine was excellent (along with the free cheese, salami and olive spread) and the server great in explaining the various wines.
author: Blake B.

description:
I got on Yelp.....typed in wine bar.....this came up~~

me and my friend decided to check it out the past saturday cuz no driving needed since i stayed at the grand hyatt. 

I walked down the stairs and it's not very big which is good. not too crowd which is good. The owner came around to recommend us this bottle of white wine. The result is.......

My friend has 3 glasses of those and i had 2 glasses.

WE LOVE IT!!!! hahaha~~~~ we picked this little corner to hide from the public so we can chat it up without disturbing anyone. 

It's a chill place with little noise level but just enough for your conversation to be heard. If you want to just chill and within walking distance from union square....i will sure recommend this place.

The waitress was so nice and she checked on us many times and also recommended our next restaurant....yummy mexican food.....check my review...
author: Eva L.

description:
If you are looking for an unpretentious, local spot to have a nice glass of wine, stop looking.  You've found it.  

The Hidden Vine has a great selection of wines with a staff that provides their customers with knowledgeable and friendly service in a cozy and intimate atmosphere.  It's a wonderful place to grab a glass before or after dinner with your closest friends or someone you would like to get to know.
author: Trisha H.

description:
4.5 stars if possible...Very homey-feel...as if you're in someone's living room.  Nice place for a laid back night out...not that classy feel, like what I experienced at Nectar; nonetheless, we still had a great time!  The place is tiny and intimate, so going with a group of 7 was tough for seating, as we had to wait a bit.  But Chad did an excellent job in accommodating us with a table. 

Loved the core rose blend. My friend had the tasting flight and she said she liked it.  We also got 3 more other bottles to share- 2 whites, one red.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I've never been to a wine bar before -- but this is what I've always imagined them to be like.  The place is somewhat difficult to find -- it's tucked in an alleyway behind a hotel.  When you walk in the door, you immediately walk down a flight of stairs to a room that looks like it belongs on the Titanic.  Plush velvet chairs, candles, warmly painted walls -- and all really crammed into a fairly small and low room with pillars holding up the ceiling.

I had a Cab Franc, which was absolutely amazing.  Now, I'm a fan of Cabs in general, but this took it to another level.  Too bad a glass cost what I usually like to pay for a bottle, so I won't be splurging on it often.  The port I had afterward was equally good, however I wished they'd give a bit of chocolate with it.

I will definitely come back here with a date.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Definitely aptly named.    Good thing I read other yelpers' reviews which directed me to look for a hotel entrance.  I think I would have been still in search of this wine bar without this crucial clue.

I found this place to be a cozy lounge as opposed to other wine bars I've been to.  Quite refreshing, however, the seating arrangement does not promote conversations outside your group so I'd suggest going with your friends or just a date.

Wine selection was interesting.  In the end, I was at a loss for what to choose so I selected a dessert wine tasting and left it up to my server to pick three.  Our server was quite nice and wanted to make sure that I selected the right wine.  I have to say that I was very happy with my three tastes and that their service was on the ball!

I'd definitely be back.
author: J L.

description: Wonderful wine list.  Wonderful flatbreads (although not cheap).  Cheesy fireplace.  Love coming here for drinks and light nibbles.
author: Hilary C.

description:
Cozy and dim, not for those who want to meet other people.  This place is definitely for couples and friends who want to talk and enjoy some good wine.  

Enter through the hotel on Post and just keep walking on back.  You'll be seated by the staff there and they are all on top of things - from making sure you get what you are looking for to making sure you never have an empty glass.  Prices were also decent.

My sister and I decided that this little wine bar was a keeper.  They have monthly specials/selections which makes coming back here at least once a month a no brainer.
author: A L.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm not a HUGE wine conniseur (sp?). I usually like Cabs, and I'm horrible with names which lends to me forgetting which ones I like.

Positive:
They have this thing called "Flights" and I just love that idea. You basically choose a White Flight or a Red Flight, and they bring you 3 out of the 5 half glasses of white wines or red wines and each month they come from different countries. One month may be Spain, the next, Portugal, France, etc. Then you can order a salami dish, a fruit dish (chocolate covered strawberries), olives, and just munch on these side dishes while you sip on the wines.

They even put the name, country, and year of the wine on these pieces of circular paper that they put on the bottom of your glasses, so you can take them off and take them home if you want to remember an excellent wine.

As Shoba D. says in a review below, it is VERY library like, dark environment, and relaxing. The place is sort of small but we've never found a hard time getting a place to sit. Might be because not a ton of people know about this place either.

Negative:
Hmmm small? Hard to find parking? it's wine. It's cheese. It's salami, fruit, and olives. Can't really complain about much and since i'm not a huge wine connieseur, I really can't say how fabulous or god aweful the wines are. But they sure are tasty to me!

Ambiance
Love it. Dark, library feel, great place to chill with friends and just chat up a storm for hours on end.

Service
The owners are really friendly, and knowledgeable, and just plain cool. They won't get in your away and intrude on you, but are friendly if you want to spark up a convo. The place is small, they're always behind the bar, they explain the wines flawlessly (using all kinds of terminology that sounds latin to me), and just plain chill

Summary
Hole in the wall, hidden gem, gets the famous 5 star of approval from me.
author: Seiji N.

description:
This is a wonderful, laid-back wine bar with a great atmosphere and very knowledgeable staff. Go here as a pre-dinner or pre-show stop on a big night out, or after work any night just to relax and unwind. 

The menu is limited, since wine is really their specialtly. But you can get a great appetizer-like plate of tasty fruits and cheeses.
author: Christine P.

description:
Love the place!! It should be called the hidden gem. Its small and cozy and has a "euro" feel to it. Perfect date spot as well as good for a long conversation over wine with a good friend.

They keep changing the wine (and cheese) selection, so everytime you go there is something new to try. They have both Californian and imported wines and do blind tastes as well as wine fligths.
author: Paawan K.

description:
The Hidden Vine is a charm if you are looking to fall in love. Take a date here, and he or she will swoon. 

My date, who is stoic and uninclined to showing emotion (by his account), was delighted. When we first got to the place, we sat in the middle on a small velvet couch. He is 6' 2" and I am 4' 10" and we were both very comfortable. Then we moved to the prized corner spot (when we first walked in there was a woman there who had taken off her shoes, and had her feet up on the leopard printed foot stool). The privacy is perfect. The wait staff is pretty discreet. Only once did the waiter interrupt while we were kissing to give us the check; he could've simply put the check on the table without saying "thank you" a  little loudly. 

We had a pinot noir that was outstanding. The cheese was also nice, although one was a bit salty. A ginger chutney complemented the whole thing. 

As I have only recently moved to the bay area, I can't compare wine bars knowledgeably (yet). I was looking for cozy, quiet and unpretentious, and I found it.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I kind of love this place.  I came here on a Saturday night for a small birthday gathering, and it was perfect.  Small, cozy, and intimate - a great place to chill out and relax over a glass of wine and chat with friends (and you can hear them when you talk).  And very reasonably priced wines (and good ones)  for $7-10/glass.  Do not come here if you are looking for a scene, dancing, or unst, unst.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Melinda C.

description: I've been wanting to try this place and finally stopped in on a Thursday night after a fabulous steak dinner.  We were expecting a dark, sultry, quiet wine bar where we could cozy up and chat.  Unfortunately, we didn't even stay for one drink - the server seemed a little harried (that's fine, we all have our days).  But the real bummer was that it is attached to a hotel lobby hallway so there was a really bright light coming in through the window which bathed part of the room in a blinding florescenty distracting glow.  We left.
author: Loralyn S.

description: Took a minute to find since it really is "hidden" in the back of a little hotel.  Not busy at all for a Thursday evening and service was great.  Wine, cheese and olives were all yummy and it feels like you're at someone's house in a cozy little parlor.  Recommended!
author: Janae J.

description: This place is a hidden jem buried in the nob hill area of sf.  I love the crowd. I love the wine. I love the location.  Arguably, the best wine bar in SF.  The staff here is amazingly nice and cordial and they know their wine!
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
Here's what I don't understand. Yelp has over 100 reviews of this place. Hidden Vine capacity sits somewhere around 30 - 40 and yet, you never feel crowded nor unwelcome. Go figure.

Four of us went to Hidden Vine after reading the rave Yelp reviews. Because there were four of us and no open tables to accommodate,  the owner kindly asked two women sitting at a four-person table if they'd mind moving to a two-person table. They obliged and we were on our way to imbibed merriment.

The whole experience is refreshing. The owner/waiter takes the time to explain the nuances between each wine within the various tastings and comparisons. Her passion shines through each description.

And then the cheese and olives. At a wine bar you often expect the accoutrement of food to seem secondary at best. Here the chew-worthy treats served as a delightful balance to the flavorful wines. We had four of the five cheeses offered and all were tasty. In addition they serve chutney and dried berries. At the end of the evening we opted for the daily selection of truffles: champagne and raspberry. They verged on too rich, yet you had no trouble going back for a second helping.

Bottom line, this is the type of establishment memories are made of. I am positive I will be back again and again to enjoy the wine, the cheese, the service, the atmosphere and, of course, the always fine company.
author: Josie Z.

description:
Do you need another review to tell you to go here??  GO HERE!  It's a nice atmosphere, the people working behind the bar were very friendly, and helped up decide on a wine.  And Fridays you get 20% off a bottle! 

It's a great place to get started for a girl's night out.  And dates!  And just about any other time as well.
author: Bailey B.

description:
Ever wanted to drink wine in a fancy room with antique chairs and sophisticatedly dim lighting while talking about really important, edgy things? Go here now. 

The wine is plentiful, reasonably priced (they have more expensive and less expensive wines depending on the size of your wallet's bulge). Always delicious choices. If you go here, you must order  a cheese plate as it will be one of the best plates of cheese, apricots, blueberries, and bread, that you have ever nibbled on daintily. 

Great place to have a chat with friends or meet after work to unwind. Unlike bars/pubs, this place actually manages to be *relaxing* in the heart of San Francisco.
author: M J.

description:
This place had a cool vibe going on. Its tucked behind the lobby for a hotel so its easy to miss, but inside is pretty cool.

Its not huge, but it wasn't too crowded on a Friday night. We grabbed a table and had a good bottle of Pinot Noir for about $25. We got some good advice from our server who seemed knowledgeable and couteous.

The place was small and cozy, had 80s music playing that night, but not obnoxious and definintely could carry a conversation with ease.

Seems like a good place to just chill with friends that isn't overly swanky or pretentious. Inside its about the size of a starbucks.
author: Varun ..

description: Upon first entering I immediately loved the place! I love the dim lighting, the fire places, the brick, the couches, it's gorgeous and sexy. The first time I came it was a Monday around 5:30 and there was plenty of seating, we sat at a table for two and when our third arrived we were moved to a bigger table. I ordered the South of the Border comparison and both wines were just OK a surprise considering Argentinian Malbecs are almost always at least really good if not great. Despite not loving the wine I loved my first visit to The Hidden Vine and immediately made plans to return that Wednesday. When I did return at 7 the place was pretty packed, we had to sit at the side bar and my friend didn't have a seat, but it worked. I ordered the San Luis Obispo Pinot Noir and we shared a flat bread mushroom pizza. My wine was amazing, so amazing that I obviously needed two glasses. The pizza was also really good, loved the crust and that they didn't put too much cheese. We also ordered the chocolate truffles and I'm not a huge fan of dessert, but these truffles were amazing! So having loved my second visit even more than my first I went back on a Saturday- we ordered the cheese plate and I stuck with the same pinot for my wine. I generally do not eat a lot of cheese, but I did enjoy some nibbles of it and definitely enjoyed my wine again!
author: Natalie M.

description: LOOOVE this place!  So cute, cozy, private and easy to have a conversation w/o having to yell over loud music.  The cheese assortment was good too.  One of my favorite places for a low key night.
author: Adriana G.

description:
What can a boy say that 157 other people haven't already written?  This place is worth all five stars and then some!  Maybe just the basics and then a story:  the wines here are always great (except when they did the month of Greek wines...I personally didn't like them), the service (read: husband and wife owners) are INCREDIBLE, the atmosphere is musty and reminds me of a basement that some eclectic grandpa would have, the prices are very fair, and generally this place is perfect for a date or a couple of friends or anybody who wants to drink some great wine in a very comfortable atmosphere. 
On second thought, why tell a story?  The Hidden Vine is great. This place makes me happy.
author: Zev K.

description:
super cozy and cute little wine bar...being inside really does make you forget about the cold, foggy awesomeness that san francisco so kindly bestows upon us at almost all times.

i love their dessert wine flight - the perfect amount! the cheese and charcuterie plate is also quite tasty (it was here that i first enjoyed the deliciousness of cypress grove cheeses), and the staff is quite helpful at suggesting wines to match the flavors.

i would give 5 stars, but a couple of the times i have been there, something seemed a little off. whether it was waiting 45 minutes for a table, or, on the other hand, the tiny space being completely deserted on a saturday night, or the service taking a little too long. they could stand to have a few more attractive by-the-glass options as well. overall, a very solid 4, if not 4.5, stars though.
author: Monica C.

description:
Now this is by far the best wine bar in San Francisco and the staff are as helpful and accommodating as any 5 star restaurant somellier and then some.  Perfect hide out, decompression session, industry get away- hang out from the madness of the world outside...
Love it and them..u know who you are...
author: sadao n.

description:
Warm inviting atmosphere, extensive menu of wines by the glass, and specials on Friday (1/2 price bottles)...what more can you ask for!?
Their by-the-glass prices seem to have gone up a bit since they first opened, but the bottle prices are still reasonable, as is whatever selection they're highlighting at any given time. Stick with the highlighted selection and you usually can't go wrong.
author: SL N.

description: They know their wine!  Great recommendations and also had some great cheese.  Great atmosphere but funky location.  Easy to find if you go through the hotel.
author: Eydie H.

description: I recently went to The Hidden Vine for a co-worker's going away party and was very unhappy with the service I received. In the outdoor seating area one of the wooden benches had sap all over the arm rest, which got all over my skirt. When I told the people behind the bar about the sap leaking bench, they just gave me a napkin soaked with soda water and said they would check it out. Sap doesn't budge with soda water. I have to get this professionally cleaned and I have no idea if it will come out or not. I know that I would have refused if they had wanted to pay for cleaning, but I was surprised that they didn't even offer. One does not expect sap in a wine bar that clearly wants to come across as high-end. They also did nothing to clean the bench to ensure that no other customers would end up covered in sap. While the food and wine were fine, good service is what really takes an establishment to the next level. I won't be going here again.
author: Paige M.

description: A little bit romantic, a little bit exciting, a little bit relaxing, a lot of fun.  And such a tasty selection of wines!
author: Mason G.

description: Great little place!  Very cozy, lots of seating options from couches to tables for 2 or 4. The server we had was great.  We were overwhelmed by the menu so we told her what kind of wine we were looking for and she suggested an excellent wine that was exactly what we wanted at a price that it that much more enjoyable.  It is a little dark but that adds to the relaxing environment.
author: Misti P.

description: Cute wine bar tucked away from the hustle bustle.  Great if you like bocce ball with a group of friends.  The decor is nice and modern.  The food and wine is varied; I can't say I'm a foodie or a wino so I'm not sure how good it all is, but sure tastes good.
author: Jon S.

description: This place is very cosy. Staff is nice. Loved the wine. Totally recommend it.
author: Love M.

description:
This place is great-- reasonable priced for good wine bottle selection, great atmosphere, and great services. 

My only complaint is the temperature-- it does get rather warm when it fills up.
author: Sue P.

description: Great service, server knows her wines. Suggested the Inzolia white. Really good! Atmosphere is really cozy and clean.
author: Markl F.

description:
Bad reviews are for the bitter.  
I am not bitter, especially at this magical cave.  Theres nothing bad to say about this wine bar, the staff is friendly and the owners are some of the most down to earth people in the business.  
Prices are very reasonable and its a quaint and warm spot to take a date to.  Even couples are welcomed here.
author: Tina d.

description: I love the HIdden Vine.  The couple that own and run it are delightful. Indeed, the guy reminds me a little of Ira Glass.  The space is cozy, unpretentious, and friendly.  Although it takes a bit of effort to find, it's a great place to chat with friends and enjoy delicious wines in an intimate setting.
author: Adele B.

description: Dark, intimate and definitely hidden.  The prices for flights are reasonable, and it's fun to do a blind tasting then reveal which glasses you like.  Their small bites are good but stinky and the whole places smells of that same stink-- cheese.
author: Rayna A.

description: Good place to quietly enjoy a glass of wine with some good friends. Was fairly empty when my 2 girlfriends and I came in but it was perfect for a chance to catch up and relax.
author: Freda F.

description:
What's the psychology here with yelp?  I don't get it.  Why do I feel the need to tell more people (like there aren't enough already on yelp raving about this place) about such a great find of a wine bar?  It is like What's the Matter with Kansas, right?  Why do I vote at yelp against my interest?  My vote here seemingly serves only to make the Hidden Vine more popular--and I think it is most likely popular enough!  Oh well.  
So, the Hidden Vine is one of those places that makes me want to go back to all my prior reviews and adjust my stars so that the 5 I am giving to Hidden Vine is more meaningful.  Everything about the place screamed "find."  
The owners are not only incredibly friendly and enjoyable to be around, but also perfectly suited personalities for running a wine bar.  Let me explain.  I love wine--so much so that I have been known to read about it, spend too much time and money collecting it, drink too much of it, and even obsess from time to time.  Is it not the world's most incredible, fascinating and utterly mind-boggling drink?  Plus, it has alcohol in it.  HOME RUN!
BUT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I hate wine assholes.  Like everything in life, some people just need to take it easy.  Other great wine bars in the city (I will not name names) employ people who take wine to a whole new level of seriousness.  I can't deal with the conversations I have with these people, with their intense name-dropping of bottles they have consumed or own, or ridiculous descriptions of the "cerebral" nature of the wine.  A great man once said that there is a fine line between clever, and stupid really.  And it's true.  Clever=loving wine and being passionate about it (as it is one of life's greatest things to enjoy), while stupid=being an asshole about it.  

OK--wow I can ramble.  The point is that Angela and David, the owners, are remarkable at walking the line and being clever, not stupid.  They have a great selection of wine.  They will tell you about the wine you are drinking.  They are clearly passionate about it.  They LOVE wine.  And it shows in the space they have created and the personality they have given to it.   The flight of California Pinot and Pinot blends we had last night was very, very well selected and very unique.  That takes love and attention.  

I have been to the Hidden Vine once, last night, for my fiancee's birthday.  In the hour I was there it soared to the top of my list of  go-to places in the city.  It is the type of place that makes you happy to live in San Francisco--the type of place I will look forward to all day.  It is a great combination of a comfortable space, a unique and enticing location, and exceptional proprietors.  
I can't wait to go back.
author: Blake W.

description:
i dont  pretend to know wines. i just know what i like. the few favorites of mines, theyve gotten the green light from people i repsect.

ive grown to respect someone elses palate even more so because of this place. 

excuse me, let me get this out of the way first....

"I AM NOT DRINKING ANY FUCKING MERLOT. "

i loved that line. 

anyways, im a big pinot noir guy. one of my favorites an etude 2004 pinot noir, 2005 is pretty good also. 

at hidden vine, picked out this navarro pinot noir......... holy crap me. 

first i was like WOW. this is awesome. i rikey berry berry mucho. 

secondly, i was like WOW, as it breathes it gets better and better. *fyi though i like my wine slightly chilled... mmm cellar temp? i also know a slightly chilled wine can cover up some imperfections.* 

then it hit me.....  i was all damn, holy crap, how much does this bottle cost? 100? 150? 200? craptard fuck me. well if im gonna pay for it, might as well enjoy it.

oooooooooooo they gots cowgirl creamery mt tam. my favorite. 

dont expect to find too much on the food side here. they have JUST enough shit to keep you happy. i really liked their dry salami. the small plate of smoke duck breast, dried italian salami, some dried fruits, mt tam and some bread, seriously, just perfect for me and my companion to nibble on while enjoying a truly great wine.

here it comes..... the bill........ be prepared. straight face, dont show weakness....... come on now, big girls dont cry.......apply ky now......

hey what the hizzy fo shizzy? that bottle was $45!?!??!?!?! no fucking way. yes fucking way. no way?!??!?! this is half of that etude i like and in my humble opinion, much better.

nice
author: Euge L.

description: The delicious Autumn K. recommended this place to me many months ago and I have been waiting for a chance to try it. Last weekend, fellow Yelper Elle Roi L. (my beloved friend of more than 12 years -- yes, we met in pre-school, dammit!) gave me a perfect excuse, as we wanted to find a quiet venue to hang out and catch up ... and this little nugget more than fit the bill. It's cozy and charming and very much tucked away, off the beaten path. You can check your pretensions at the door, too, as they're very laid back and just want you to enjoy the vino, whether you're a connoisseur or a novice. To quote the creepy old lady from the movie Poltergeist, "All are welcome. All are welcome."
author: Gregor G.

description: Cute little place. Staff was knowledgable but a tad stuffy. Food choices limited. Most importantly, I didn't like one of the four reds in my flight. I was quite disappointed. I'm not a snob but do usually find a wine or two that I want more of.  Not this day.  They tend to focus on small wineries with limited production. Maybe that limits their offerings a bit too much? Probably will not return.
author: Dave M.

description: I love the dark, wine colored atmosphere of this place.  The mix of seating styles (couches, bar stools, an adorably romantic nook) made for a great eclectic feel. I didn't think it was stuffy, but intimate and comfy.  The server was very knowledgeable of the wines, of course, I'm not in the know on wines so maybe he was no expert, but knows more than me. I prefer whites so started with a flight of them, then moved to the reds, and was completely lost by then and tried much of my friends wines too.  They were all good, although I recommend trying them in smaller doses.
author: Cara J.

description:
We thought it was a joke when we were stopped at the door on Friday night. 
Guy at Door:  "I'm sorry you can't go in, it's too crowded."
Me, hand on door:  "Yeah, ha ha." *starts to push door *
GaD:  "No really.  We're over capacity.  You'll have to wait for two people to come out."
Me:  "Wow, seriously?  Uh, okay."  * stands watching door *
Aside from it being a very packed version of your wealthy aunt's parlor, this place is my mecca.  A nice cozy atmosphere for cuddling in and tasting wine and comparing wine and sampling wine and sharing wine and blind tasting wine and trying new wines and talking about wine with other people who like wine and basically just drinking wine?  
The world could've exploded Friday night and I would've gone quite happily to the other side, wanting for nothing.  Oh, except maybe whatever that delicious roasting onion smell was, since I know they only have cheese plates here.
A great place to catch up with a friend or two, or make out with a cute boy (or girl) over a couple of glasses of wine while snuggled into a cushy chair, but definitely not a place you come with 15 of your nearest and dearest, or as a stop on the bachelorette party train.
From now on if I'm not at home, I think you can probably find me here, trying to tell the difference between the Croatian whatchamacallit and the California Zin (I failed miserably by the way).
author: Jennifer D.

description: Thanks to yelp, we decided to try this wine bar during our families 1st visit to San Fran on valentine weekend.  My husband, brother-in-law and I were looking for a good wine bar and this was just what we wanted:  an intimate wine bar that is serious about wine.  The prices were great for a remarkable flight of pinot's, and Jared recommended a fantastic bottle of pinot when we finished our flight.  We ordered a cheese tray, olives, and truffles - holy cow!  Jared's wife (I can't believe I forgot her name, she was so cool!) was so nice, and she and her husband Jared were so knowledgeable, I wish they were here 'cause it would be my favorite hang out!  Best of luck to Jared on your wine!
author: Stephanie P.

description: I found this place by accident, but it was a Friday night and way too crowded. Managed to find it again, with the help of calling them from Post and Mason, and found it again. Great wine, nice flights, non pretentious attitude from the serving trons. Great idea and nice place to have a mellow chit chat after work, drink after close, meet a mafia guy from China, and join the white slave trade. Seriously.
author: Anna B.

description:
I went here last night with a friend after finding it on Yelp, and had to add my $.02 on the place. First, as they say, timing is everything. We walked in and were lucky to have found a seat on the cozy couch, since all the tables and 'bar seating' were filled. In the time we sat there (about an hour) a lot of people came in - couples, large groups, etc. - and had nowhere to sit, so they left, however, if those groups had come in 30-45 minutes later they would have found plenty of seating. I guess it's better to have a small bar that people have to be turned away from than a large bar that feels empty. You know, the allure of what they are missing.

Now, to the wine and food. The wine selection was really nice. We both prefer sweet white wines and bubbly, so having a choice of sparkling wines and at least 2 different Rieslings was a big selling point for us. The service wasn't bad, since the place was pretty busy. Our waiter was aware of us being there, gave us a sufficient amount of attention as well as a sufficient amount of space. My biggest complaint had to be the food choice/presentation. The picture on their website looks so professional, while what we were given looked far different. The cheese was good, the salami very good, and the olives OK, though there were far more than I have been given at other wine bars, they just weren't that special. The presentation, however, really lacked the professional element I expect from a wine bar that only serves cheese, meats, and olives. The chutney was alright, and paired well with the cheeses. The serving utensil was a regular knife, where a cheese spreader would have been much more compatible with the meal, as well as a small spoon for the chutney. These may seem like fairly nit-picky items, but when out with friends/a significant other/date/spouse, serving should still be relatively simple.

All-in-all, $50 for 2 glasses of wine, 2 cheese selections, 1 salami, olives, and a few baguettes was a little much for the overall experience. I have had better wine, food, and service at less-trendy places.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Nice wine bar with a good selection of wines. Friendly waiters, relaxed atmosphere.
author: Jolie S.

description: Perfect cozy place to enjoy a riesling flight or two. Great selections. These people have wonderful taste. Their wine list is wonderful and full of gems. The service and knowledge was supurb. Definately have to love the cozy chairs for a make out session. A marvelous place to start or end your evening.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
awesomely awesome.  that's my favorite word and this is my new favorite wine bar.  we looked at the menu for this place one time and i wanted to go in, but my friends were all about the beer so we walked away =(

now, several months? a year later? found a friend who has a taste for the wine as well.  yay!!  the menu was decent with the wines categorized by flavor like "lightly sweet" or "fruity and jammy" or something like that.  i went with the featured white on the front page (NV carrod frres clairette de die 'tradition).  and it couldn't have been tastier.  oh wait, not true.  it was made tastier with the cheese plate we ordered.

you can pick 2 cheeses for $12 and it comes with sliced baguette, wheat crackers, dried blueberries, dried apricots, cranberry-tangerine chutney and some other stuff i can't recall.  we were instantly able to pick out the 2 cheeses we wanted: the cowgirl creamery mt tam (triple-cream) and the tome de couserans (semi-soft).  oh man, the cowgirl one was fabulous.  butter soft and sweet like cheese should be.  i could feel myself putting on an extra pound but it was well worth it.  the tome was also tasty, even when compared to the cowgirl.  nice texture and a light flavor.

wow, i want to go back already.  that's how great this place is.  and that's even without having taken into consideration how super friendly, helpful, and accommodating the server was and how comfy the seating was and how intimate and cozy the place felt overall.  umm, can we get another star for this place?

wow, i went back and the server guy totally recognized me.  that's funny.  and this time i tried the flight of 3 dessert wines and was so happy with 2 out of the 3.  i wasn't as happy with the cheese plate though.  way less cheese this time and no tasty wheat crackers!  it was fine though as i really didn't need to eat all that triple cream and the focus really should be the wine.  still 5+ stars!
author: spiff e.

description: A nice little place to chill. A bit dark and dank for my liking though. It had an old musky smell about it. They have a large selection of wines, both bottles and by the glass (average $10). It is a bit hidden, hence the name. Either enter from the Fitzgerald hotel or Cosmo Pl.
author: Jun W.

description: I've gone to The Hidden Vine twice and had a great experience both times. My friends and I love wine and cheese so this was the perfect place for us. It is a very cozy wine bar inside the Hotel Fitzgerald. The customer service is excellent here. The girl who helped us both times took the time to explain to us the different wine flights, meats, and cheeses, answered all of our questions, and made suggestions. This place is good for dates and small groups. The setting is very intimate and good for conversation since it doesn't get really loud like your typical lounge or bar. We will definitely be going back for more!
author: Jessica S.

description: The owners of The Hidden Vine have passion for wine and it shows. Their wine selections are varied and totally fabulous, and they're more than willing to help you pick out something that suits your tastes. The Hidden Vine is cozy, inviting, and the perfect romantic place to enjoy a glass of wine.
author: Brianne K.

description:
What a lovely hidden gem.  I went to this place for a friend's birthday celebration on a Wednesday night, and it felt like we were in a lovely European inn, where we could get cozy & linger for hours.  Which we did!  I had the Pinot wine flight, and our server was so kind and knowledgeable - and the wines were great, and unusual.  I had 2 more glasses of wine just based on her descriptions which were spot-on. We ordered a selection of cheeses & meats to share, as well as the olives.  All were very good - there was a Mt. Tam, and a cheddar, and a goats' cheese - and paired well with the tomato and cherry chutneys that were on the side.  If they had served more food - we would have stayed all night!  But I also liked the fact that it's limited to drinks and small snacks - otherwise it would surely be overrun with people and not as intimate.  Loved it.  Go with a friend you have not seen in awhile and spend quality catch-up time.

Update 12/06:  Enjoyed yet another friend's birthday celebration here, and felt the same warm fuzzy for the place.  Even with our large party, the HV was accommodating and the service was personal.  I had a Rhone wine flight that was delightful, and I especially appreciated the descriptive tags they put on the bottom of each glass.  It's not a hidden destination anymore, but it is still a great choice of venue to enjoy wine in a friendly, intimate setting.  You can use Le Colonial's valet parking, which is $6 for an hour.  Go!
author: Liz S.

description:
Please go to The Hidden Vine.  
It is warm and unpretentious, giving you the feeling of hanging out in your friends' apartment who happen to not only love wine but, want you to love it too.  I get the feeling the owners just want to make the world a little happier by sharing their delicious wine and knowledge. 
And what a fine contribution to the world they make.  Everyone should enjoy life as much as they do.  Plus, when you order a flight, they hand write little descriptions on pieces of paper around the stem of the glass.  So much care and attention goes into this place.  Also, the descriptions are very helpful when by the third glass of the flight, you are having trouble recalling just which glass contained that lovely South African wine you must try again.  Then you look again and see that the owners already took care of that problem, writing the name down before you even knew you would need it.  Now, that is service- completely anticipating your needs and not even having to ask.
author: Nina W.

description: The hubby and I came here before a show at the Punchline for a drink. It's down a little alley and you could miss it if you didn't know it was there. Overall I really enjoyed the ambience and will definitely be back. The guy who helped us was really nice and attentive.
author: Melinda R.

description: I am neither a wine geek or a fan of wine bars, so when I give this place 5 stars understand that it really has to be quite exceptional for me to like it this much.  Spent an evening here with some friends and couldn't have had a better time.  This place is full of great comfortable seating, a great wine selection, staff that REALLY know their stuff, and a nice clientle.  The cheese tray we got was exceptional, and every one of the recommended wines was fantastic.    I'm not a huge fan of wine, but this place could really turn me into one.  Highly recommended.
author: Joshua W.

description: Today's Daily Candy reminded me of this little joint.  Was here on a weeknight (sadly, not a Thursday) and thoroughly enjoyed a bottle of Trefethen riesling and a lovely cheese plate with chutney.  Quite frankly, I didn't know I was a chutney fan until I came here -- but McQuade's Celtic Chutneys are tasty and locally made (http://www.mcquadechutneys.com/), and the mandarin & apricot selection we had went very well with the cheese.  Yum!  Comfy chairs and the friendly owner pouring make this a place I'll come back to.  :)
author: Nat K.

description: I didnt feel the same as others on this place. Cute, yes. But I thought the help was very disinterested in helping us find seating after waiting a very long time, and in general very unfriendly. It was very cramped for a weeknight. My experience was very sub-average and I havent been back, that was 8 months ago.  Wine choices were good though. Luckily we knew what we liked, because if we had to ask for help I doubt we would have received it.
author: renee m.

description: Its not *that* hidden.  There are actually two entrances; the other being through the Fitzgerald Hotel on Post Street.  I like how if you get a wine flight, they give you like, three full pours. Friendly servers. I like how its address is "1/2 Cosmo Place".
author: Rick H.

description:
After dinner, we came to HV for a 2nd round of drinking wine... prices are def reasonable, especially since we're speaking of SF standards...

Hidden indeed!  Def a great place to come wine tasting minus the vineyard experience! Great selection of wine, munchies and flights! Its def not a romantic, poshy type of lounge, but truly comfortable, to the point of making me super sleepy, I felt like I was in someone's living room ... lots of seating throughout, but can get packed, and paintings throughout...i swear, the VIP seating is prolly the one that you will face as soon as you make it down to the last step.. just simply turn to your left, and it's like this hidden gem .. hahha, with mini curtains that drapes over the person facing the wall. but anyways, if you're truly lucky, try to snatch the one that's facing towards the crowd, and take those 3 cushions and make yourself comfy, and get away. HAHAHHA... i apparently made myself TOO comfy that i ended up lying down, and making myself just TOO DAMN COMFY. 

mmm .. the Navarro pinot noir ... =D (wouldn't say it was my fave, but that pretty much made me content for the evening, or did it not? what an evil spell that made me all sleepy for the rest of the evening on a sweet blissful night...*snorts)

Staff: quite friendly & knowledgeable ...

Environment: Cozy, warm ... 

Parking: Valet right outside. (since i didn't drive, i didn't have to think twice on where to park)
author: Jennifer S.

description: This a great hidden treasure! Fabulous place to meet your friends for a cozy chat and a great Cabernet.
author: Sandy S.

description: I honestly don't know what I can add here, because other reviewers have said it all: low-key, intimate, cozy, wonderful..... I can't think of a better spot for a date or just some great conversation. The wines are unusual, carefully selected, and beautifully described. The staff is attentive and knowledgeable. The big red plush chairs are so comfy, it's hard to get yourself out of them (particularly after a big glass of syrah!). I couldn't recommend this place more highly.
author: Leslie F.

description: I'm no wino...I mean wine connoisseur, but I'm sure the staff at the Hidden Vine can lead you in the right direction to becoming one.  This is a nice subterranean gem.  Nice comfy seats.  Cozy atmosphere.  Great place to unwind with friends or someone special.  Ask the staff to help you pick out something nice to taste.   I would've enjoyed a more modern look, but I suppose it fits with the alley decor.
author: JeFF T.

description: The BF hit another one out of the park with this suggestion for a drink prior to "Putnam County" (which I also recommend)  Went with the wine flights, and was pleasantly surprised when they appeared to be full servings.  cheese plate was well done.  Cute ambiance, intimage, great date idea.
author: Beth V.

description: Angela and David (the owners) are the least pretentious and non-condescending wine lovers you could ever hope to meet. This is a comfortable place to have a bottle of wine with friends that's not scene-y.
author: Michelle J.

description: Thanks Yelpers!!!  I wouldn't have found this place without y'all.  I was looking for somewhere in a narrow neighborhood that fit the nice/cozy/casual/classy vibe that is so hard to find, and the Hidden Vine was perfect.  The owner, who I met the next day when I returned to retreive my credit card, seems great and the place shows how much the owners enjoy running it.  A true gem.
author: J P.

description: They should rename this place "The not so Hidden Vine" because every time I go here the place is packed.  That could have something to do with the fact that it is super small, but one could say that its size is what makes it  such a cozy wine drinking experience.  I do wish that it were a bit larger though, when the place is full its a bit difficult to have a conversation with those across the table from you.  The wine selection is pretty good and ever changing... the sommeliers are very friendly and knowledgeable so be sure to pick their brain if you don't know what you're in the mood for.
author: Ms. M. M.

description: This is exactly the kind of place you'd want to find yourself at on a cold San Francisco night, curled up with a glass of wine and engrossed in good conversation. Cozy is an understatement when describing this tiny out-of-the-way oasis situated nicely in the heart of downtown SF. A trip down a small staircase leads into a room decorated a la Sherlock Holmes, equipped with wooden book shelves and dim lighting. I recommend sampling their flights (they come with cute labels so you don't have to sort out which is which in your drunken haze). In short, your experience at the Hidden Vine will be worth the half hour you spend looking for the place and the hour it'll take you to find parking.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Seems like quite the treat for those in the know in SF.  Being a fan of all things wine-related, I liked this place a whole lot.  A cozy and classic atmosphere with a wonderful, friendly staff.  The wine selection was choice (I had a Pinot Noir from Mendecino - dry, tangy, and delish) and the cheese selection was phenomenal, although I'm not sure anyone else got to taste it considering I basically parked myself by the platters (listen, I don't fuck around when it comes to cheese).  I can see it getting a little crowded on a normal night now that the word is out - 91 reviews can't be wrong, but the Yelp Team filled it up just right.  I feel I could impress some locals with my knowledge of this place.
author: Sam P.

description: What's not to like? Nice space. Friendly, knowlegible staff. Great wine selection.
author: Stanley T.

description: The Hidden Vine "gets it." Unpretentious, great, interesting wines that are organized for both the wine enthusiast and the novice. The atmosphere is comfortable, laid back, but also has a nice old world feel.  Perfect for an afterthought to Le Colonial or as a primary destination. We ate a fantastic meal at Le C. and finished the night off with two terrific wine flights at The HV. Highly recommend the Pinot comparison. Great value! Keep up the good work Angela and Dave!
author: Phil M.

description: Super fantastic.  I went there for my birthday and had an amazing time.  i had already heard so many great things about the place that I was starting to think that there was no way it would live up to my expectations.  I was wrong; it by far EXCEEDED my expectations.  The place is so cute, warm, cozy and inviting.  David and Angela were SOOO down to earth and clearly passionate about what they do.  i will definitely be back.  FYI, the Navarro . . . delicious.  Oh, and I love the handwritten wine tags.  It gives the whole experience a very personal feel.  Loved every second!
author: Marla L.

description: Try as you might, you'll find no pretense here.  Instead you'll get a cool little wine bar with the atmosphere of Sherlock's wooded study and a Seattle-chill crowd.  The Vine offers a varied and interesting selection of small plates and wines, including ever-changing tasting flights.  The cheapest drinks run around $10+ for a glass or featured flight (2-3 smaller glasses), which is reasonable, and pours are substantial.  Perfect on either end of your evening, as a low-key start or a wind-down night-cap.
author: MScott S.

description: This place is great. Went here on a date and we both had a good time. We got a few of the wine flights and they were all very tasty. Generous pours too. Angela that works there is an absolute gem. Very knowledgeable, friendly, not at all pretentious, perfect hostess. Free munchies were the icing on the cake. When we went they had a selection of 3 cheeses including a really yummy manchego, french bread, and salami for no charge. This is my new favorite wine bar.
author: Marky M.

description:
THX Yelpers for letting me in on this secret....loved it! From the size of the pours to the knowledgable staff, from the selection to the prices...loved it!
Definitely be back esp for the "second label"  flights!
author: dawn w.

description: Hands down my favorite wine bar ever.   My boyfriend and I go on a regular basis because we love the ambiance (cozy. with sort of an elegant shabby chic decor), the wines...pretty much everything.  But what really makes the place special are the owners, David and Angela, who know how to make their guests feel comfortable and welcome.  I can't recommend this place more highly.  Go ye and drink!
author: Dana F.

description: It's wasn't bad, OK, sure -- but it was also rather, uh, unspectacular. Do ya'll really think this is a nicer wine bar than, say, Hotel Biron or Cav? What gives? Definitely not worth going out of one's way, I say.
author: Canby T.

description: I would be a regular at The Hidden Vine if I lived in San Francisco. Unfortunately, I was just in town for a few days, but still managed to go twice. It's just such an unassuming place with a really great, friendly, and knowledgeable staff. We got a spot on recommendation for a wine flight (generous pours!) and the server was very helpful in picking out some appetizers that matched perfectly. She also recommended a great restaurant (well, 5 actually).
author: Andrew E.

description: It's no secret that this wine bar is no longer hidden :( It's always been packed when I've gone, but of course that's because it's just that good. Anyway, it's a great place to do some wine tasting because they've got a great selection of wines, cheese plates and flights AND they provide you with the names of each wine on the coaster so you don't have to discreetly write it down on a napkin so you don't forget!
author: Natalie T.

description: If you are going to wine and dine her or him, this is a good place to start.  It's very romantic.  A Tuesday or Wednesday is probably your best bet.  Cheese and sausage night on Thursdays may leave you without a place to sit.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Really! Its Hidden. If you're standing in front of the Fitzgerald Hotel, go through the lobby and you'll hit the  bar!  I love their European vs Napa wine flights. It was fun to compare and contrast the wines and gab with the great knowlegable wine staff.  They could only give me a 1/2 pour of one of my wines in the flight but made up for it by giving me another wine to try to make up for it. . .AWESOME!! Some good snacks for noshing, but don't expect a full meal here. Great for before or after dinner.
author: Roseabelle M.

description:
well, it looks like the secret's out.  
my friends and i have been coming here since the first month the hidden vine opened, and it's been our favorite hangout for the past few years.  

the best thing about the hidden vine is that you walk in, and you immediately feel like a guest in your friend's living room. (which is the complete opposite feeling that you get across the street at le colonial, see my review.)  it's a little quirky, a little warm and lived in, but it's home.  and your hosts are pouring.

you really can't say enough about the owners - they're just good peoples.  they're not wine snobs or wine experts, but wine fans, and they're trying to make you a fan as well.  they're not trying to teach you about wine, but to get you to try new things, to decide for yourself what you like and what you don't.  every month there's a new theme, and very reasonably priced flights of reds or whites at $12.

so yes, i'm a fan.  to all the other fans out there, cheers.
author: brian w.

description: Great out of the way wine bar....it's tucked into a cozy space in a random hotel..and that randomness extends into the bar's decor a bit (cheesey artwork and knick knacks).  but the place is comfortable with sofas and candles, not a big "scene", the proprietors are knowledgeable and incredibly nice, the wine list is fun and changes frequently....a great place to sample flights of wine and cheese trays- you can make a night and a meal out of it.
author: Greg A.

description: This place is an awesome mellow wine lounge. It is kinda scary going to this place because it is in the TL, but if you like wine, check this place out. I was impressed by how simple yet nice this place is. The employee's are nice and patient. They waited forever for me to decide on a glass of wine and even gave me a few suggestions.
author: Tyler D.

description: A great place to unwind after a day of work or to just chill and catch-up with friends while sipping on great wine and nibbling on delicious cheese.  Very warm and cozy.
author: Shiho F.

description: A great little wine bar and they put out very tasty cheese and meats. Way, way crowded on the Thursday after work we visited  and I hate having to hover but I actually didn't mind, the place is that nice and friendly. A different region is featured every month and the Languedoc nightly special really was a steal.
author: patrick g.

description: ...4th Spot of the Night Definitely Hit the Spot...reminded me of a library back at berkeley...it's a good thing...for a wine bar...very comfy...very inviting...this spot hit the spot...because by middle of it we sang...little mermaid songs freely...we compared two different white wines...go for white...doesn't spot your teeth...hehe...very friendly staff...i'd come back here any nite...this may have been my fav spot of the nite...
author: Wendy H.

description: I love that this place still feels undiscovered, ie: overcrowded and scene-y.  The owners make this place a winner because they obviously have a passion for the wines they sell and they do a really good job explaining the wines without being obnoxious.
author: Helen C.

description: Immediate seating at 8 pm on a Saturday night deserves four stars off the bat.  Pair that with the most amazing rose tasting flight that I've ever had and you've got gold.  This place is going to be a go to for pre-dinner drinks downtown, absolutement.
author: Claire C.

description: Great place for a date or just to hang out and talk.  The atmosphere of this neatly tucked away gem in SF is chill, the wine is good, and it's a great place to take someone you want to get to know better.  We've been twice, using the place as a pre-dinner warm-up, and have been charmed both times: the selection of wines is great, offering both Californian rarities, and imported wines-- it was really fun to do one of the "comparisons", where they serve two related wines, but don't tell you which one they are until after you've sampled them.  The server was really knowledgeable about wines, and seemed to enjoy telling us about them!  Lovely place.
author: Dominique L.

description: This place is adorable! It has a vibe of a speakeasy and tea-dance-twenties that is enhanced by the fact that it's accessed through a hotel called "The Fitzgerald." They offer lots of options for wine flights, which is great if you're indecisive like me. My only gripe is that service was extremely slow for a place so intimate.
author: Rochelle F.

description: Small, plush furniture, laid back but elegant. Good wines with a range of prices. Perfect for an after-work drink or for a quiet evening out in the City. Would recommend stopping by Hidden Vine then, if you want a more upbeat atmosphere, head to Le Colonial across the way.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I have traveled the world in search of a good wine bar, and this one is the best in San Francisco. Good deals, unpretentious, friendly.

5 stars even though it's popularity has caught up with it and it can be difficult to grab a seat in one of their, like, 7 chairs.
author: Jenna F.

description: It feels like you're in an old library in a mansion a la Wuthering Heights or something, but once you get over that, there's nothing stuffy about this nook. The owners know their wines and remember faces, so you'll feel welcome and in good hands immediately. The menu changes monthly and they are constantly researching new ways to present and compare wines and wine regions. Certain nights have themes. I believe you get a discount on bottles every Friday!
author: sarah s.

description: My aunt brought me to this place last weekend to meet a friend and I was pleasantly surprised!!! The place is very romantic, cozy and inviting and the wine was very good. It's a little pricey though and probably did not appeal to pals my age, but I still love it. If u want a romantic ambience and leisurely  conversation, then this is the place for u!
author: Adele V.

description:
i know everyone and their brother loves this place, so perhaps that's why i was a touch underwhelmed when i finally visited it. it's like when everyone raves over a movie and then you go see it only to find that it was  just ok. the letdown can be intense. luckily with the wine bar you still have the fact that there is wine to help keep your spirits buoyed. 

don't get me wrong, it's not bad. the service was attentive and friendly, the space cozy and oh-so-intimate. however, this place does still feel like a hotel bar. and not a new, funky hotel bar, but a slightly older, more genteel one. complete with carpet. anyone who knows me knows how i feel about carpet. just yucky. tho this carpet did seem cleaner than most. 

the wine list is great and pretty extensive. and i was quite happy with the comparison option. 2 half-glasses for about $10 or $11. plus these are generous half-glasses. the complimentary cheese plate is also a nice perk. all said, i would definitely come back here on a chilly, blustery san francisco evening. it's a little too dungeon-y for a nice night.
author: rachel p.

description: What a great little place tucked away in a little alley and downstairs.  Very cozy couches and armchairs, a fireplace, and great wines and hors d'oeuvres,
author: Asteridae A.

description: This place feels less like a 'bar' and more like a 'lounge' with its cozy chairs, dim lighting and mellow ambiance.   The selection of wines represents all the major regions, and the wine flight selections are never boring. I tried a flight from Hungary and Montenegro which I hadn't had the opportunity to try before.   Not much in terms of solid food options but the cheese plate which was a perfect match with the wines-the staff was definitely helpful in suggesting which cheeses would pair best.
author: Smruti S.

description: Great!!  Wonderful place to hang out with friends (or a date). Great cheese selection to complement an interesting wine list. Definitely a low key bar so don't expect a party but it's a great place to relax with a delicious glass of wine....or three.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This place is so cozy with lots of cute little nooks. The wine list has flights and varietal and regional comparisons. The staff is friendly and attentive.
author: Monika M.

description: What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said?  It is great.  Angela and Dave the owners are super and have so much to offer about wine to anyone who will listen.  I love their monthly region features.
author: Katie P.

description: Cute and cozy decor.  Nice atmosphere for a first-date, a small group of friends, just want to catch up with someone.  The owners are adorable and very helpful.  Don't know much about vino?  No fear, the staff is very able and willing to help you choose your wine and even suggest different food options to accompany them.
author: Caitlin L.

description: I'm sorry, but any place that has "The Quiet Storm" for background music I take issue with...  The lite jazz that they place is synonymous with the cheesy decor, and while it has potential to be a cozy, tucked away spot, the carpet made me seasick.  Otherwise, it was fine -- service was very pleasant, wine selection interesting.  No, it's not a scene (thankfully), and yes, it may be unpretentious, but the smooth jazz was killin'.
author: marie m.

description: What a find!  Very cozy and unpretentious!  The owners, Angela and David, are friendly and helpful.  Each month they highlight wines from a different region.  They offer flights of wine from those regions, red or white.   Or you can also try a flight comparing the current month's red (for example) versus the California equivalent.  They will tell you about the wines and give you honest opinions.  Prices are reasonable, and the cheese selection is great!  Perfect place to go on a date or when you're wanting to catch up with an old friend.
author: Chibi Q.

description: my favorite wine bar in the city.. this location is the perfect environment to lose track of time with the right person(s)  with an awesome selection of vino, comfort, and conversation. I really enjoyed their featured selection from South Africa many many moons ago..
author: Dori C.

description: Just after we picked out a lovely bottle of something from the night's featured region of Languedoc, I realized that AC/DC was playing...I mean, it wasn't Bon Scott era AC/DC, but it was a song off Back in Black, and that's totally respectable.
author: L W.

description:
i love going to places that require walking downstairs to get in - makes it feel like you're going into a secret hiding place.  

and once i arrived in the main room - i automatically felt like i was in someone's living room: cozy little tables (that reminded me of our round card table when i was a kid), warm fireplace, a little sofa/chair vignette....small bar in the back.  it all felt so "unpretentious private club"

but the best part was the owner who served our wine and told us the most interesting and specific details about the wineries, the varietals and the winemakers themselves.  the amount of knowledge that came forth from his mouth was totally impressive.

i put in my request for the Cinque Terre region - where i explained i had a sweet dessert wine (sciacchetra) that made me feel the most memorable sense of happiness experienced from a taste of wine that i've ever expereinced.  i have faith that if anyone can bring this delight to the states - it's the Hidden Vine.

the cheeses and assorted salami-esque meats were a lovely compliment to our pre-dinner wine excursion.

a delightful place!
author: Kate F.

description: After a bum tells you exactly where the "Hidden Vine" after looking for it unsucessfully a bit.. you are in for a good experience at Hidden Vine.  Sure, like any other wine bar it has comfortable seating, a diverse wine menu, and little plates of food.  But the wine bar's service is what sets it apart.  If you order a flight, expect about a 2 minute summary of each wine and what you should look for while drinking.  The location is small so come early so you can get seats.
author: Marc M.

description:
I came here once for the first time.
I loved it!
I know absolutely nothing about wine, I been to Napa and always end up forgetting everything I've learned.

This is the place!
They served us the same wine from different wineries (France/California) and the wine glasses had an upside down note on them with the information. 
I loved comparing them and guessing which one is from where.



Small perfect for a date!


NOTE: You have to walk inside the Hotel otherwise you WONT find this place...
I walked for 15 minutes and I couldn't find it...well HIDDEN Vine...but it's really Hidden!


Enjoy.
author: Geena T.

description: This is a gem of a place.  Located in lower nob hill down in an alley between post and sutter you will find the hidden vine.  A choice wine bar with a really interesting selection of flights,wines by the glass, and bottles.  I've been hear twice and both times I had some fantastic wines and a great time.  Note to guys:  Lots of cute girls seem to hang out here, and they are actually presentable girls that you could take home to your parents.  God I love this place.
author: Francis K.

description: So glad FiDi has a nice new wine bar to replace the old time favorite Press Club. Nice menu, staff, location, decor, vibe. Great place to go on a weekday. Extra bonus: 50% off with Yelp check-in, the only incentive for me to do a check-in
author: P I.

description: The Hidden Vine is a rare find in any city, I think--a quiet, unpretentious wine bar that has great offerings, kind, knowledgeable owners who actually work there and talk to you about what you'd like, and a cozy, "welcome to your grandmother's living room" kind of feel.  I have been there several times and have never had a problem finding a comfortable seat, and every flight and glass of wine I've tried has been great.  They also have a nice selection of little plates of food to enhance the wine you choose.  By far my favorite after-work spot to meet friends...
author: Caroline G.

description:
I used to love this place back when David and Angela owned this gem. They made this place a very welcoming and intimate spot. I wish I can say the same about the new owners and management. When I first talked to them on the phone, they exuded an attitude and thought it not a good sign. When I finally visited the place, it confirmed my notion.

The server was curt and seemed to be in a bad mood. And they don't mingle with the patrons the same way David and Angela did. I felt like I had to trip them in order to get noticed.

I called them later on to politely lament this fact t bec. I used to really love this place and I wanted the warm experience back and I thought they could benefit from some patron input. But I received an attitude that says "tough" and  the man I talked to really didn't care about what I had to say. When I ask for his name, he hung up the phone. When I called back, they stopped picking up the phone.

I simply decided it's not worth the effort. David and Angela brought the friendliness with them when they left. It's a lost gem and decided never to return again.
author: Sylvius W.

description: How is it I live a building away and I have never seen fellow Yelpers there. I guess I was seeing double as Dave and Angela get me feeling pretty good. Love the choice of music, the wine list (totally random in a good way) and the owners, and I can stumble home!
author: Jason D.

description: Hidden Vine is a hidden gem nestled between Cosmo Alley and Post Street. Service is super friendly and welcoming. I thoroughly enjoyed the Five Vintners Zinfandel. Minus one star for the mildly claustrophobic interior.
author: Jess H.

description: This is a place that makes me want to get into wines. Tucked away under a hotel, it's like a secret hot spot where only those "in the know" go. Super cozy, with poofy, low, lounge-y chairs... feels like you're chillin' in someone's living room. Perfect ambiance, and not too loud so you can actually hear your date. Great staff, friendly service, great wine. Definitely will be back for one of those wine flights!
author: Joy C.

description:
How could I have forgotten to throw in my two cents for the Hidden Vine! This place is awesome! Seems like most of you Yelpers have discovered what a fun, laid back unpretensious wine bar this is.
David and Angela, the owners are the best! They have a great love and appreciation for wine and are able to share that in a fun, casual way.
The only drawback is it's getting too popular and since the space is pretty small when it get's crowded, it can be uncomfortable. On a recent Friday night, some idiot invited everyone in her office and there was just not enough room for all those people! Did they get a clue? No! We were sitting at a table trying to enjoy our wine while these yahoos were crowding around us and sticking their butts in our faces. So rude!
When it's not packed though, Hidden Vine is a lovely place to relax with a flight , a few glasses or a bottle and chat with David & Angela.
Yeah Hidden Vine, we love you!
author: Scott C.

description: What a pleasure to visit this place and meet the owners!  After another super whack run at Le Colonial, I dropped in Hidden Vine and was lifted from the funk that had settled by a fresh white Italian spritzer recommended by the owner extrodinaire.  It was a surreal moment of happiness and the next suggestion just kept it going.  The laid back vibe with the amazing wine selections and chill tunes make this a pure triumph.  Thanks for putting me back on track last night!
author: Porfirio R.

description:
Yes, this is a hotel bar.
Yes, the wine list isn't the biggest.
Yes, you have to walk down a back alley to come in one of its entrances.  
BUT, this is one of those hidden gems because when you're sitting there relaxing with friends on a couch, enjoying a nice glass of wine and sharing a good conversation in an intimate setting you don't think about the above mentioned downsides.  
What you do realize is that its not crowded, pretentious, or uncomfortable and that is what makes this place great.
author: Mike F.

description: Nice, cozy, comfortable place with nice selection of wines and the cheese was yummy. This place is hard to find, it's hidden in a basement of a hotel. It's so "hidden", even on a Friday night, it wasn't that crowded. Perfect place to go hang out with friends and have a glass or two of good wine.
author: Maya G.

description:
A very chill bar and very cozy. 

I agree with whoever said this place feels 'undiscovered'--it feels like you've stumbled upon a hidden gem when you come to the Hidden Vine.

I always get so wasted here!
author: Nicole R.

description:
Not much more to add to all of the wonderful things said here about the Hidden Vine.  It is cozy with a very knowledgable staff.  It is a great place to unwind.  And they not only offer flights, but compares.  For compares, you get half a glass of two different wines.  What a great way to find a favorite.
  My only complaint is that I have heart disease which means that I cannot eat any of their food offerings.  That only gets me inebriated (drunk) quicker so that I have to quit drinking wines sooner.  Life stinks!
author: John H.

description: Cozy, comfortable spot. Don't remember if there was a fireplace here but it sure did feel like there was. This is a great meeting place for those Friday happy hours, when you are happy it's Friday, but don't necessarily want to battle loud music and loud peeps.
author: Janet C.

description: The flight is the only way to go.  Coming from a self-proclaimed wine "sans connaissance" (does that make sense?), it's a great way to try three wines and decide what you like.  It doesn't matter how many points it got, where the vine was conceived or how long it has had to breathe...You either like it or you don't.  At Hidden Vine, they'll tell you what you may or may not taste (when there's supposed to be tar, coffee, currant, raspberries and oak all in one glass, it's easy to miss something).  If you're hungry, get the cheese platter - yummy.
author: ellyk E.

description: It was just packed enough, carpeted in that old-twenties style, with tables and wood-and-leather chairs.  I had the red wine sampler and liked them all.  Fun and cozy.  I'll be back.
author: Elizabeth P.

description: I love dessert wine. I love cheese. The Hidden Vine does both perfectly. You can get a tasting of three different kinds of dessert wine for $13 and the world's most generous cheese plate for $12. I'm in love.
author: Noelle Q.

description: This is still a lovely, cozy place for a low key glass of wine. But I'm sad (although not really surprised) to report that a bit of the magic left with Dave and Angela.
author: Leigh M.

description: When I first heard about the Hidden Vine and its fabulous wine selection, I thought dark, modern, sleek, and mysterious.  It actually is more of a warm hotel lobby bar with florals, wood, crimson, and comfort. The cheese plate was delish and the sparklings were terrific.  They have a cute Fitzgerald coat of arms above the pseudo fireplace of candles and uber comfy chairs that just suck you in and let you relax.  I missed out on the secret alley entrance b/c we entered from the hotel, but definitely a wine delight!
author: Tara G.
